trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP for Floods Associated with Tropical Storms in Honduras is activated through a dual-trigger mechanism. Trigger 1 must be met first, which is a forecast of a tropical storm with a certain probability and intensity within 3 to 5 days. Once Trigger 1 is met, Trigger 2 is evaluated, which is a hydrological forecast indicating a probability of river flooding with a 10-year return period within a 3-day lead time. Only when both triggers are met does the EAP formally activate and initiate most early actions. Preliminary actions can begin after Trigger 1 is met. There is a stop mechanism that halts all actions if the storm weakens or changes trajectory significantly during the forecast period.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: If during the third day of the forecasted lead time the event decreases in intensity to a tropical disturbance, or if the event abruptly changes its predicted trajectory according to competent forecasting authorities, all planned and/or underway actions under the EAP must be halted immediately. If forecasts continue to meet thresholds and the event maintains or increases its category, all planned activities must proceed as scheduled.

trigger_statement_1.statement: Trigger 1 ⎯ CENAOS or NOAA issues issues a forecast with ≥60 per cent probability that a tropical storm (≥34 knots) or stronger will reach the alert zone within 3 to 5 days.
thresholds: 60 per cent or greater probability
Tropical storm with wind speed of 34 knots or stronger
Forecast lead time of 3 to 5 days
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: CENAOS, NOAA
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Alert zone in Honduras including river basins such as Ulúa, Chamelecón, Patuca, Choluteca, Humuya, Cangrejal, Coco, Segovia, coastal areas, Sula Valley, Central District, and Costa de los Amates
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Preliminary early actions that do not require EAP funds may be carried out, such as communication and coordination activities, community preparedness messaging, and readiness checks.

trigger_statement_2.statement: Trigger 2 ⎯ When the GEOGLOWS/GloFAS model indicates a ≥50 per cent probability of river flooding with a 10-year return period in high-risk flood zones, within a 3-day lead time.
thresholds: 50 per cent or greater probability of river flooding
Flood magnitude with a 10-year return period
Forecast lead time of 3 days
trigger_statement_2.source_authority: GEOGLOWS/GloFAS model
trigger_statement_2.geographic_scope: High-risk flood zones in Honduras, including major river basins
trigger_statement_2.condition_dependency: Trigger 2 is conditional on Trigger 1 being met first; Trigger 2 formally activates the EAP.

trigger_mechanism.description: The Simplified Early Action Protocol (sEAP) for floods in the White Nile River basin is triggered based on a statistical machine learning model (INFLOW-AI) that predicts the change in the Sudd wetland inundation extent two months ahead. The model runs continuously from June to December with updates every ten days (dekads). The sEAP is activated if the predicted increase in inundation extent exceeds a 5% threshold compared to the seasonal minimum. There is no stop mechanism as flooding is slow-onset and actions are implemented immediately upon trigger activation.

trigger_statement_1.statement: The Simplified Early Action Protocol (sEAP) will be triggered in June, in anticipation of the maximum flood extent of the White Nile in September based on the INFLOW-AI model (see more information below) run every 10 days. The sEAP will be activated between 1 June and 30 September if the statistical model predicts the change in the Sudd inundation extent from the seasonal minimum to the forecasted maximum extent over the next two months to be greater than 5% then the early actions will be activated. This model runs continually from June to December to provide updated two-month-ahead of inundation forecasts every dekads (ten days) that will enable the sEAP to be reassessed throughout the flood season. This sEAP does not have stop mechanism, the flooding is slow-onset wetland flooding rather than sudden onset flooding, and all actions will be implemented as soon as the sEAP is triggered.
thresholds: Predicted increase in Sudd inundation extent over the next two months greater than 5% compared to seasonal minimum
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: INFLOW-AI model developed through the INFLOW project, shared by South Sudan Flood Taskforce Technical Working Group
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: White Nile River basin and Sudd Wetland, South Sudan
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Beneficiary selection and registration one month ahead of peak flooding; distribution of essential household items activated when trigger is reached; post-distribution monitoring; early warning dissemination; coordination of anticipatory actions in Health, WASH, Shelter sectors; support evacuation and PGI activities including referral pathways for SGBV cases.

trigger_mechanism.description: The Simplified Early Action Protocol (sEAP) for flood risk in Malawi uses a multi-stage, tiered trigger system combining forecast-based and observational data. It begins with a monitoring phase based on seasonal weather outlooks and rainfall forecasts, followed by a pre-activation (Tier 1) based on forecast-informed readiness thresholds, and full activation (Tier 2) based on real-time river gauge readings and inundation modeling. The triggers are linked to specific catchment areas and flood-prone districts. There is a stop mechanism that suspends all actions if daily forecasts indicate a reduction in anticipated rainfall.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: All early actions will be suspended if the Department of Climate Change and Meteorological Services (DCCMS) daily forecasts indicate a reduction in anticipated rainfall amounts.

trigger_statement_1.statement:
Following a thorough analysis of the available forecast services and skill capacities in the country, it was agreed that MRCS will use the following trigger statement:
Phase 1: Monitoring
Monitoring of the trigger will be initiated when the Department of Climate Change and Meteorological Services issues a seasonal weather outlook indicating normal to above-normal rainfall, with a high probability of wetter-than-average conditions expected between November and March. This includes anticipated rainfall totals exceeding the seasonal average of 800 mm to 1,200 mm across the identified catchment areas. Upon issuance of this forecast, readiness and preparedness actions will be activated.
Phase 2: Activation
The activation of the sEAP will follow Malawi’s agreed trigger system – a tiered activation model outlined in the National Anticipatory Action Framework.
thresholds: Seasonal weather outlook indicating normal to above-normal rainfall
High probability of wetter-than-average conditions expected between November and March
Anticipated rainfall totals exceeding the seasonal average of 800 mm to 1,200 mm across identified catchment areas
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Department of Climate Change and Meteorological Services (DCCMS), Malawi Red Cross Society (MRCS)
trigger_statement_1.lead_time: Seasonal outlook (months ahead), readiness activated upon forecast issuance
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Identified catchment areas in Malawi
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Readiness and preparedness actions will be activated upon issuance of this forecast.

trigger_statement_2.statement:
The Simplified Early Action Protocol is pre-activated when the Department of Climate Change and Meteorological Services (DCCMS) issues an alert followed by a warning, triggering Tier 1 – Forecast-Informed Readiness, based on:
• Rainfall forecast of ≥100–150 mm within 72 hours in key basins (Shire, Linthipe, Lake Chilwa, etc.), with 3–5 days lead time.
• Cyclone forecast predicting ≥100 mm of rainfall within 24 hours in flood-prone districts, with 3–5 days lead time.
• Rainfall forecast combined with exposure analysis showing ≥30% of households at risk, with 3–5 days lead time.
The sEAP will be fully activated for Early Actions under Tier 2 – Observational and Activation when:
• River gauge readings exceed the alert stage at ≥2 stations (real-time trigger).
• Inundation modelling projects ≥30% of households affected in flood-risk zones, with 2–5 days lead time.
The trigger will prompt MRCS to implement prioritized Early Actions outlined in the intervention plan. All actions will be suspended if DCCMS daily forecasts indicate a reduction in anticipated rainfall amounts.
thresholds: Rainfall forecast of 100 to 150 mm or more within 72 hours in key basins (Shire, Linthipe, Lake Chilwa, etc.)
Cyclone forecast predicting 100 mm or more rainfall within 24 hours in flood-prone districts
Rainfall forecast combined with exposure analysis showing 30% or more of households at risk
River gauge readings exceed alert stage at two or more stations (real-time)
Inundation modelling projects 30% or more of households affected in flood-risk zones
trigger_statement_2.source_authority: Department of Climate Change and Meteorological Services (DCCMS), Malawi Red Cross Society (MRCS)
trigger_statement_2.lead_time: 3–5 days for forecast-based triggers; 2–5 days for observational triggers
trigger_statement_2.geographic_scope: Key river basins and flood-prone districts in Malawi, including Shire River Basin, Linthipe, Lake Chilwa, Salima/Linthipe/Rifidzi, North Rukuru Catchment, South Rukuru Catchment
trigger_statement_2.condition_dependency: Pre-activation (Tier 1) based on forecast triggers must occur before full activation (Tier 2) based on observational data.
trigger_statement_2.preliminary_actions: Upon Tier 1 trigger, MRCS activates National Response Team (NRT) to prepare for activation, disseminate early warnings, verify pre-targeted households, notify financial service providers, and confirm cash distribution points. Upon Tier 2 trigger, MRCS implements prioritized early actions.

trigger_mechanism.description: The simplified Early Action Protocol (sEAP) for cholera in Zimbabwe uses a multi-stage trigger mechanism with three consecutive phases of activation. Each phase is triggered by specific epidemiological events related to confirmed cholera cases and evidence of community transmission. The phases escalate interventions from initial rapid response and capacity building to more sustained and resource-intensive actions. The protocol does not include a traditional stop mechanism but employs a scale-down approach at each phase if outbreaks are contained or do not spread further.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: No traditional stop mechanism is included due to the possibility of cases re-emerging or going undetected. Instead, a scale-down mechanism is applied at each phase to taper activities if outbreaks are contained or do not spread beyond initial locations.

trigger_statement_1.statement:
Due to the complex risk factors that impact the likelihood of onwards transmission of cholera, The sEAP adopts a staged intervention which uses separate triggers to initiate three consecutive phases of action.
Phase 1: Trigger: A confirmed cholera case in any district of the country will trigger:
• In the affected district mobile Surge Team will be deployed to support rapid investigations, provide BORT trainings and support Rapid Response Team (RRT) capacity.
• In Harare: BORT teams will be deployed to disseminate community level cholera messaging and surveys to inform targeting (environmental hazards and Free Chlorine Residual (FCR) tests)
Phase 2: Trigger A case confirmed in Harare will trigger:
• Rapid Response Teams investigations which will be supported in target areas
• Branch Outbreak Response Team deployment with NFI’s to support targeted distributions and continued cholera awareness information dissemination
• The distribution of inline chlorinator tablets to areas identified by the assessments under Phase 1
• ZRCS begin developing DREF document to anticipate needs and actions outside of Harare
Phase 3: Trigger Evidence of community transmission in Harare and spread to additional districts
• BORT members deployed with NFI and ORPs
• Surge Team continue to support a limited capacity to respond to outbreaks countrywide, preparing for more sustained interventions
thresholds: Phase 1: A confirmed cholera case in any district of the country
Phase 2: A confirmed cholera case in Harare
Phase 3: Evidence of community transmission in Harare and spread to additional districts
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Zimbabwe Red Cross Society (ZRCS) sEAP based on Government of Zimbabwe case and outbreak definitions
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Nationwide Zimbabwe with specific focus on Harare and other districts
trigger_statement_1.condition_dependency: Phase 2 activation depends on confirmation of cases in Harare following Phase 1; Phase 3 activation depends on evidence of community transmission in Harare and spread to other districts following Phase 2
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions:
Phase 1: Deploy mobile Surge Team for investigations, provide BORT trainings, support Rapid Response Teams, deploy BORT teams in Harare for community messaging and environmental surveys including Free Chlorine Residual tests.
Phase 2: Support Rapid Response Teams investigations, deploy Branch Outbreak Response Teams with NFIs, distribute inline chlorinator tablets, develop DREF document for outbreaks outside Harare.
Phase 3: Deploy BORT members with NFIs and Oral Rehydration Points (ORPs), Surge Team supports limited capacity countrywide preparing for sustained interventions.

trigger_mechanism.description: The Early Action Protocol (EAP) trigger mechanism for sudden floods in Mauritania is based on a dual-trigger system. The first trigger (pre-season) prepares logistical actions such as pre-positioning, training, and local coordination based on seasonal probabilistic forecasts. The second trigger (short-term, 5 days ahead) activates the implementation of early actions on the ground based on short-term extreme precipitation forecasts and hydrological monitoring. The second trigger can activate the protocol independently of the first to ensure maximum responsiveness. There is no mention of a stop or deactivation mechanism.

trigger_statement_1.statement:
L'établissement de seuils clairs, tels que des précipitations prévues dépassant les niveaux historiques de déclenchement des inondations, permettra de garantir que le système soit à la fois opportun et exploitable, en équilibrant l’anticipation à long terme avec les capacités de réponse rapide. Cette approche intégrée fournira un mécanisme robuste pour atténuer les impacts des crues soudaines en Mauritanie. L'énoncé de déclenchement est une définition résumée des conditions dans lesquelles le PAE sera activé. La justification des systèmes utilisés pour les déclencheurs suivra dans les sections suivantes. Dans le cas de la Mauritanie, un déclencheur à 2 moments est convenu : 

 o Déclencheur de pré-saison : 
 • Prévision par le CEPMMT SEAS5 d'une probabilité de 40 % ou plus que les précipitations totales saisonnières soient supérieures à la normale. En d'autres termes, il s'agit d'une probabilité de 40 % ou plus pour le tercile supérieur. 

 o 5 jours - Prévision de précipitations extrêmes Déclencheur 
 • Les prévisions de l'ECMWF pour un EFI > 0,8 et de l'ONM prévoient une quantité de précipitations supérieure à 25 mm pour les 5 prochains jours. 
 • La SONADER dispose d’un réseau des stations hydrométriques qui permet de suivre la situation hydrologique du fleuve en période de crue et de décrue. En effet des bulletins hydrologiques seront partagés régulièrement avec le CRM.
trigger_statement_1.statement_english:
The establishment of clear thresholds, such as forecasted precipitation exceeding historical flood trigger levels, will ensure the system is both timely and actionable, balancing long-term anticipation with rapid response capabilities. This integrated approach will provide a robust mechanism to mitigate the impacts of sudden floods in Mauritania. The trigger statement is a summarized definition of the conditions under which the Early Action Protocol (EAP) will be activated. The justification of the systems used for triggers will follow in subsequent sections. In the case of Mauritania, a two-moment trigger is agreed upon:

 o Pre-season trigger:
 • Forecast by CEPMMT SEAS5 of a 40% or greater probability that total seasonal precipitation will be above normal. In other words, a 40% or greater probability for the upper tercile.

 o 5-day extreme precipitation forecast trigger:
 • ECMWF forecasts an EFI > 0.8 and ONM forecasts precipitation exceeding 25 mm over the next 5 days.
 • SONADER has a network of hydrometric stations that monitor river hydrological conditions during flood and recession periods. Hydrological bulletins will be regularly shared with the Mauritanian Red Crescent (CRM).
thresholds: 40% or greater probability that total seasonal precipitation will be above normal (upper tercile)
ECMWF EFI > 0.8 forecast
ONM forecast of precipitation exceeding 25 mm over the next 5 days
Hydrological monitoring bulletins from SONADER
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: CEPMMT SEAS5, ECMWF, ONM, SONADER
trigger_statement_1.lead_time: Pre-season (months ahead) for first trigger; 5 days for second trigger
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Mauritania, specifically high-risk zones: Trarza, Brakna, Gorgol, and Guidimakha
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: First trigger (pre-season) allows preparation of logistical actions such as pre-positioning, training, and local coordination. Second trigger activates early actions on the ground including evacuation, distribution of kits, and mobilization of volunteers.

trigger_mechanism.description: The Early Action Protocol (EAP) for the Indus River divides the river into three stretches and six sections, each with specific triggers and thresholds based on real-time water flow levels, 24-hour flood forecasts, and other risk indicators. Pre-activation triggers primarily rely on the Global Flood Awareness System (GLOFAS) forecasts or weekly weather outlooks for certain sections, while activation triggers depend on observed flood outflows and quantitative flood forecasts from the Flood Forecast Division (FFD), Pakistan Meteorological Department (PMD), and Pakistan Irrigation Department (PID). Early actions are implemented only in sections where thresholds are met. The trigger system is manually operated with continuous communication among PRCS, FFD, and disaster management authorities. There is no stop mechanism once early action is initiated, but evacuation support is conditional on observed flood outflows exceeding thresholds.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: This EAP does not include a stop mechanism once early action is initiated. However, evacuation support is only activated when observed flood outflows exceed specific thresholds at key upstream monitoring stations.

trigger_statement_1.statement: Pre-Activation Trigger: Each river section along the upper, middle and lower Indus River system has its trigger statements/criteria for pre-activation and activation. Most of the pre-activation triggers in this EAP are using the GloFAS predicting flood flows greater than 2 -year return to 5-year return period with a probability of more than 70 percent at respective upstream gauging stations, with lead time ranging from 3 to 10 days depending on the river section/stretch in question. The exception to this is the riverine floods in the Kabul and Swat River sections, where weekly weather outlooks from the PMD are used for pre-activation purposes.
thresholds: Flood flows greater than 2-year return period to 5-year return period with a probability of more than 70% at respective upstream gauging stations
Weekly weather outlooks from PMD for Kabul and Swat River sections
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Global Flood Awareness System (GLOFAS), Pakistan Meteorological Department (PMD)
trigger_statement_1.lead_time: 3 to 10 days depending on river section
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Upper, middle and lower Indus River system, including Kabul and Swat River sections
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Continuous monitoring and validation by PRCS with technical support from RCCC

trigger_statement_2.statement: Section 1: Kabul & Swat River (Lead Time: 6 hours): The trigger for Nowshera district will be reached when the observed flood flows in the Kabul River at Nowshera station, as reported by FFD are at a very high flood level (i.e., over 200,000 cusec), while the trigger for Charsada district is reached when the observed flows in the Swat River at Munda Headworks as reported by PID are at a very high flood level (i.e., over 150,000 cusec).
thresholds: Observed flood flows in Kabul River at Nowshera station over 200,000 cusecs
Observed flood flows in Swat River at Munda Headworks over 150,000 cusecs
trigger_statement_2.source_authority: Flood Forecast Division (FFD), Pakistan Irrigation Department (PID)
trigger_statement_2.geographic_scope: Section 1: Kabul & Swat River, Nowshera and Charsada districts

trigger_statement_3.statement: Section 2: Indus River - Tarbela to Taunsa (Lead Time 48 hours) The trigger will be reached when Bulletin B i.e., Quantitative flood forecast at gauging stations from the FFD predicts: • Flood inflows in Indus at Tarbela of 400,000 cusecs or above in the next 24 hours or • High flood inflows in the Indus at Kalabagh of 500,000 cusecs or above in the next 24 hours or • High flood inflows in the Indus at Chashma of 550,000 cusecs or above in the next 24 hours. However, the evacuation of people and livestock will only be triggered once the observed river outflows of the Indus surpass the aforementioned thresholds at those respective gauging stations.
thresholds: Flood inflows in Indus at Tarbela of 400,000 cusecs or above in next 24 hours
High flood inflows in Indus at Kalabagh of 500,000 cusecs or above in next 24 hours
High flood inflows in Indus at Chashma of 550,000 cusecs or above in next 24 hours
trigger_statement_3.geographic_scope: Section 2: Indus River - Tarbela to Taunsa
trigger_statement_3.preliminary_actions: Evacuation triggered only after observed river outflows surpass thresholds

trigger_statement_4.statement: Section 3: Indus River - Taunsa to Panjnad (Lead Time: 4 days) The activation trigger will be reached when both of the following criteria are met: • FFD confirms the observed outflows in Tarbela to be at flood levels above 400,000 cusecs, or observed flood outflows of Indus at Kalabagh are above high flood level i.e., 500,000 cusecs or observed flood outflows of Indus at Chasma is above 550,000 cusecs. • Bulletin B from the FFD predicts high flood inflows of above 550,000 cusecs in the Indus at Taunsa in the next 24 hours. However, the evacuation of people and livestock will only be triggered once the FFD confirms the flood outflows in Taunsa are observed above 550,000 cusecs.
thresholds: Observed outflows in Tarbela above 400,000 cusecs or observed flood outflows of Indus at Kalabagh above 500,000 cusecs or at Chashma above 550,000 cusecs
Forecasted high flood inflows above 550,000 cusecs in Indus at Taunsa in next 24 hours
trigger_statement_4.geographic_scope: Section 3: Indus River - Taunsa to Panjnad
trigger_statement_4.condition_dependency: Both observed outflows and forecasted inflows criteria must be met
trigger_statement_4.preliminary_actions: Evacuation triggered only after observed flood outflows in Taunsa exceed threshold

trigger_statement_5.statement: Section 4: Chenab River Trimmu to Panjnad (Lead Time: 24 hours) The trigger will be reached when Bulletin B i.e., quantitative flood forecasts from FFD predict high flood inflows of the Chenab River at Trimmu (i.e., 300,000 cusecs or above) in the next 24 hours. However, the actual evacuation of people will only be triggered once the FFD confirms the observed flood outflows of the Chenab River in Trimmu are above high flood level i.e., 300,000 cusecs.
thresholds: Forecasted high flood inflows of Chenab River at Trimmu of 300,000 cusecs or above in next 24 hours
Observed flood outflows of Chenab River at Trimmu above 300,000 cusecs
trigger_statement_5.geographic_scope: Section 4: Chenab River Trimmu to Panjnad
trigger_statement_5.condition_dependency: Evacuation only triggered after observed flood outflows exceed threshold

trigger_statement_6.statement: Section 5: Indus River - Panjnad to Guddu (Lead Time: 4 days) The trigger will be reached when any of the following criteria are met: • The Bulletin B i.e., quantitative flood forecast from the FFD predicts high flood inflows of above 550,000 cusecs in Taunsa or the quantitative flood forecast from the Flood Forecast Division (FFD) predicts high flood inflows of above 550,000 cusecs in Indus at Taunsa in the next 24 hours or • The Bulletin B i.e., quantitative flood forecast from the FFD predicts high flood inflows of above 300,000 cusecs in Chenab inflows of above 300,000 cusecs in high flood inflows in Chenab at Trimmu or Punjnad in the next 24 hours. However, the evacuation of people and livestock will only be triggered once FFD confirms the observed outflows of the Indus River at Taunsa are above 550,000 cusecs or observed outflows of the Chenab River at Punjnad are above 300,000 cusecs.
thresholds: Forecasted high flood inflows above 550,000 cusecs in Indus at Taunsa in next 24 hours
Forecasted high flood inflows above 300,000 cusecs in Chenab at Trimmu or Punjnad in next 24 hours
Observed outflows of Indus River at Taunsa above 550,000 cusecs
Observed outflows of Chenab River at Punjnad above 300,000 cusecs
trigger_statement_6.geographic_scope: Section 5: Indus River - Panjnad to Guddu
trigger_statement_6.preliminary_actions: Evacuation triggered only after observed outflows exceed thresholds

trigger_statement_7.statement: Section 6: Guddu to Kotri (Lead Time: 3-5 days) The trigger will be reached when any of the following criteria is met: • FFD confirms the observed outflows of the Indus River in Taunsa is above high flood levels of 550,000 cusecs and that of Chenab River at Panjnad is above high flood levels of 300,000 cusecs. • Bulletin B i.e., quantitative flood forecasts from the FFD predict very high flood inflows in the Indus River at Guddu or Sukkur (i.e., 700,000 cusecs or above) in the next 24 hours. • FFD confirms that high flood flows are observed in the Indus River at Kotri (i.e., 450,000 cusecs or above) for 3 consecutive days or more. However, the evacuation of people and livestock from subsequent tehsils will only be triggered once FFD confirms the very high flood levels are observed in Guddu or Sukkur (i.e., 700,000 cusecs or above).
thresholds: Observed outflows of Indus River at Taunsa above 550,000 cusecs and Chenab River at Panjnad above 300,000 cusecs
Forecasted very high flood inflows in Indus River at Guddu or Sukkur of 700,000 cusecs or above in next 24 hours
Observed high flood flows in Indus River at Kotri of 450,000 cusecs or above for 3 consecutive days or more
trigger_statement_7.preliminary_actions: Evacuation triggered only after observed very high flood levels at Guddu or Sukkur exceed threshold

trigger_mechanism.description: The trigger mechanism is based on the 2-week cumulative precipitation forecast issued by the Directorate General of Meteorology (DGM) of Madagascar during the rainy season. The activation trigger is reached when the weekly forecast bulletin for the river watersheds and flood warnings predict exceptionally high precipitation greater than 150 mm cumulative rainfall in a week. This trigger activates anticipatory early actions within 3 to 7 days lead time. The trigger uses both meteorological forecasts and local river level observations to confirm flood risk and identify vulnerable communities for early intervention.

trigger_statement_1.statement: Currently, the Directorate General of Meteorology (DGM) of Madagascar regularly publishes the 2-week forecast bulletin, in the rainy season, accessible on the DGM website: 2-weeks precipitation forecast: This forecast covers a 2-week period and provides an estimate of the cumulative amount of precipitation per week, in the form of district-based mapping. This information in the form of 2 maps makes it possible to visualize the districts likely to receive significant rainfall in a week. Knowing that a watershed can cover 2 or more districts Trigger mechanism (1 to 7 days delay): The activation trigger will be reached when the weekly forecast bulletin of the river watersheds and the important flood warnings/advisories predict exceptionally high precipitation heights: greater than a cumulative precipitation of 150 mm (i.e. in the category of "abundant" according to the DGM classification, see Appendix) After the activation trigger within 3 to 7 days, the MRC will initiate the process of disseminating early warning messages and bulletins (evacuation messages) to the target population along the Matatana and Manapatrana River basin. It is important to note that the weekly DGM forecast used will be coupled with local information based on local population knowledge of the behavior of the Matatana and Manapatrana rivers. Markers (often natural such as rocks or trees) are identified by the local population so that the rise in water levels will be confirmed when the water level reaches these beacons. It should also be noted that in the rainy season, with heavy rain, the DGM also issues daily heavy rain (and flood) vigilance bulletins for the monitoring of rising waters. With the modelling tool, the cumulative rainfall predicted by the DGM will be transformed into the height of water accumulated on the surface and in the flood zone and therefore the identification of the most vulnerable communities. The activation trigger with a 3–7-day delay will also trigger the identification of the most vulnerable communities for the intervention of anticipatory actions (in consultation with the respective provincial and district management authorities), followed by the validation/registration of the beneficiaries of the assistance, as anticipatory actions.
thresholds: Cumulative precipitation greater than 150 mm in a week (category "abundant" according to DGM classification)
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Directorate General of Meteorology (DGM) of Madagascar
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Matatana and Manapatrana River basins, specifically the communes of Vohipeno, Vohitrindry, and Anosivelo in Madagascar
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: After trigger activation, dissemination of early warning messages and evacuation bulletins to target populations; identification of most vulnerable communities in consultation with provincial and district authorities; validation and registration of beneficiaries for anticipatory assistance; use of local river level markers to confirm rising water levels; monitoring of daily heavy rain and flood vigilance bulletins during rainy season.

trigger_mechanism.description: The Early Action Protocol (EAP) trigger mechanism is based on a single weather-related trigger derived from the Climate Outlook Bulletin issued by the Directorate of Meteorology and Hydrology (DMH). The trigger activates when there is a 50% or greater probability that rainfall will remain in the lower tercile (below normal levels) for the December to February quarter, indicating a likely drought. This forecast-based trigger provides a lead time of approximately 3 months before the expected drought impact. Secondary indicators such as daily river-level forecasts are used for prioritization but do not trigger activation. The trigger is monitored and validated by the Paraguayan Red Cross in coordination with meteorological and health authorities. There is no explicit stop or deactivation mechanism described in the document.

trigger_statement_1.statement: The triggering criterion will be determined by the Climate Outlook Bulletin (Click here) issued by the Directorate of Meteorology and Hydrology (DMH), which identifies a 50% or greater probability that rainfall will remain in the lower tercile between December and February, which would imply a reduction in precipitation for the quarter compared to normal levels for that time of year. The window between the alert and the imminent impact of the drought is considered to be 3 months.
thresholds: 50% or greater probability that rainfall will remain in the lower tercile (below normal levels) for the December to February quarter
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Directorate of Meteorology and Hydrology (DMH)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Paraguay
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Preliminary actions include monitoring meteorological and socioeconomic forecasts, validating triggers by the Directorate of Programs and Operations of the Paraguayan Red Cross, coordinating with local and regional authorities, and ensuring alignment with community needs. Early actions such as training volunteers, selecting vulnerable families, prepositioning seeds and agricultural implements, repairing water infrastructure, and preparing cash transfer mechanisms are undertaken from EAP approval to activation declaration.

trigger_mechanism.description: The Early Action Protocol (sEAP) uses a dual-trigger system where Trigger 1 is based on drought occurrence affecting a significant population in identified woredas, and Trigger 2 is based on epidemiological data of cholera cases (confirmed or suspected) in the same or neighboring woredas. Trigger 2 can be activated either sequentially after Trigger 1 or independently. There is a stop mechanism to deactivate the sEAP if certain conditions are met.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: The sEAP will be stopped if any of the following occur: confirmed cholera cases are identified during any triggers within the activated area; if 5 suspected cholera cases are not identified within a week at the end of the lead time of Trigger 1 (drought); or if during Drought Trigger 1 activation there is no indication of decline in surface water resources one month after the start of the drought season compared to normal season, based on Ministry of Water and Energy monitoring. The Ethiopian Disaster Risk Management Commission (EDRMC) leads and signals the stop mechanism in close consultation with the Technical Working Committee (TWC).

trigger_statement_1.statement:
Scenario 1: When trigger 1 and 2 are activated sequentially
Trigger 1: ERCS will activate the first trigger of the sEAP
• When the monthly EDRMC disaster report confirms the occurrence of drought affecting 32000 people in any of the 20 identified woredas, with a 3-month lead time.
EDRMC issues a monthly disaster incidence report by collecting information from all woreda’s who has experienced any disaster within the month, this report is shared with all relevant stakeholders who work on humanitarian settings, ERCS will be among the ones who will be receiving this report. The ERCS focal person will review this report monthly to see the occurrence of drought (due to its slow onset nature drought incidents are reported on the monthly disaster report).
Trigger 2: ERCS will activate the second trigger of the sEAP when
• one confirmed case is reported by EPHI in a neighboring woreda/district of the 20 identified woredas/districts, within the same country or in a neighboring district of bordering country with a 7-day lead time, or
• five suspected cases that qualify the clinical case definition of EPHI are identified within a week in the 20 selected woredas/district with a 7-day lead time.
Suspected cholera case: any person aged 2 years or more presenting with acute watery diarrhea and severe dehydration or dying from acute watery diarrhea as reported by EPHI.
Confirmed cholera case: A suspected case in which Vibrio cholera O1 or O139 has been isolated from their stool as reported by EPHI.
thresholds: Drought affecting 32,000 people in any of the 20 identified woredas as confirmed by monthly EDRMC disaster report
One confirmed cholera case reported by EPHI in a neighboring woreda/district of the 20 identified woredas/districts within the same country or neighboring district of bordering country
Five suspected cholera cases qualifying EPHI clinical case definition identified within a week in the 20 selected woredas/districts
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Ethiopian Disaster Risk Management Commission (EDRMC) for drought data; Ethiopian Public Health Institute (EPHI) for cholera case data
trigger_statement_1.lead_time: 3 months for drought trigger; 7 days for cholera case triggers
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: 20 identified woredas in Somali, South Ethiopia, and Tigray regions
trigger_statement_1.condition_dependency: Trigger 2 activation is conditional on prior activation of Trigger 1 in this scenario
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: ERCS focal person reviews monthly EDRMC disaster reports for drought occurrence; ERCS receives weekly EPHI disease surveillance reports and email notifications for confirmed cholera cases to monitor triggers

trigger_statement_2.statement:
Scenario 2: When Triger 2 is activated independently
ERCS will activate the second trigger of the sEAP when
• one confirmed case is reported by EPHI in a neighbouring Woreda/district of the 20 identified woredas/districts within the same country or in a neighbouring district of bordering country with a 7-day lead time, or
• five suspected cases that qualified clinical case definition of EPHI are identified within a week in the 20 selected Woredas/districts with a 7-day lead time.
thresholds: One confirmed cholera case reported by EPHI in a neighbouring woreda/district of the 20 identified woredas/districts within the same country or neighboring district of bordering country
Five suspected cholera cases qualifying EPHI clinical case definition identified within a week in the 20 selected woredas/districts
trigger_statement_2.source_authority: Ethiopian Public Health Institute (EPHI)
trigger_statement_2.geographic_scope: 20 identified woredas in Somali, South Ethiopia, and Tigray regions
trigger_statement_2.preliminary_actions: ERCS receives weekly EPHI disease surveillance reports and email notifications for confirmed cholera cases to monitor triggers

trigger_mechanism.description: The Early Action Protocol (EAP) for cold wave in Bangladesh is activated based on weather forecasts from the Bangladesh Meteorological Department (BMD) and ECMWF. The trigger requires specific meteorological conditions to be met for 3 consecutive days affecting multiple districts, with a lead time of 4 days and a forecast likelihood of 70% or more. The trigger combines multiple thresholds related to minimum temperature, departure from normal temperature, maximum temperature, and wind speed. There is a stop mechanism that can deactivate the trigger if subsequent forecasts indicate a reduced likelihood of a cold wave event before early actions start.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: The stop mechanism is triggered when a later forecast, before the start of early actions, indicates a reduced likelihood of a cold wave event. The national meteorological office or disaster risk management authority signals the stop. In such cases, procured in-kind items are stored for future use and cash interventions are halted in coordination with financial service providers to avoid unnecessary costs. Information about stopping the activation is promptly shared with communities and stakeholders through SMS, community meetings, and local coordination to ensure transparency and maintain trust.

trigger_statement_1.statement: Trigger will be activated when BMD forecasts minimum temperature goes below (<=7 0C) or the departure from normal temperature is equal to or below the 2nd percentile (3 to 4 0C) and maximum temperature goes below or equal 5th percentile (18-200C) or wind speed exceed 5th percentile (>5 km/hr) for 3 consecutive days, affecting three or more districts partially (>=50% area of the district). The lead time will be 4 days and BMD and ECMWF weather forecasts will be monitored during this season (December to February) and checked against the criteria of activation.
thresholds: Minimum temperature less than or equal to 7°C
Departure from normal temperature equal to or below the 2nd percentile (3 to 4°C)
Maximum temperature less than or equal to 5th percentile (18-20°C)
Wind speed exceeding 5th percentile (>5 km/hr)
Conditions sustained for 3 consecutive days
Affecting three or more districts partially (at least 50% area of each district)
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Bangladesh Meteorological Department (BMD) and ECMWF
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Bangladesh, specifically three or more districts affected partially (>=50% area of the district), during December to February season
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Monitoring of BMD and ECMWF forecasts during the cold wave season; readiness activities including beneficiary database development and updating; pre-positioning of stocks; community awareness; and preparation for early action implementation upon trigger activation.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP for cholera in Somalia uses a dual-trigger system with two main triggers (T1 and T2). T1 activates low-cost early actions based on epidemiological, environmental, and contextual risk factors, while T2 activates a full range of early actions based on epidemiological and surveillance data. T2 can be activated independently of T1. There is a stop/scale-down mechanism based on attack rate thresholds and absence of cases over a defined period, allowing phased and time-bound scaling down of activities with flexibility to re-scale if triggers are met again.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: Scaling down follows a phased and time-bound approach, guided by attack rate thresholds (<0.1% to 2% in rural areas, <1% to 5% in crowded urban/IDP settings) and absence of reported cases over seven consecutive days (e.g., ORPs without cases may be deactivated). The sEAP may transition to response if outbreaks escalate beyond capacity or if other partners increase support. Lessons learned are integrated into contingency plans.

trigger_statement_1.statement:
The first trigger T1, activates low-cost early actions: 

T1 can consist of the following scenarios identified as drivers of AWD/cholera epidemics in Somalia based on historical patterns:  
1. A confirmed cholera case or spikes in AWD cases in a neighboring location to the selected PAMIs. 
2. Activation of the SRCS drought EAP (MDRSO019) 
3. The following amplifying factors occur in a selected PAMI, based on previous scenarios in 2017 and 2024, that led to large scale outbreaks.  
a. Flooding and extensive rains 
b. Drought followed by heavy rains 
c. Drought EAP is activated 
d. Increased malnutrition rates (GAM cases reaching the threshold of >10%) coinciding with heavy rains, flooding, or droughts
thresholds: Confirmed cholera case or spikes in AWD cases in a neighboring location to selected PAMIs
Activation of the SRCS drought EAP (MDRSO019)
Flooding and extensive rains in selected PAMI
Drought followed by heavy rains in selected PAMI
Drought EAP is activated
Increased malnutrition rates (GAM cases >10%) coinciding with heavy rains, flooding, or droughts
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Somali Red Crescent Society (SRCS), Ministry of Health, National Disaster and Food Reserve Authority (NADFOR), Somalia Acute Malnutrition Projection dashboard
trigger_statement_1.lead_time: Up to 3 months from T1 activation to likely T2 activation
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Selected PAMIs in Somalia including Garowe and Bosaso (Puntland), Borama and Burao districts (Somaliland)
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Low-cost early actions activated including proactive reporting by SRCS branches and volunteers, community-based surveillance (CBS) reporting where feasible, and communication with Emergency Operations Centre (EoC) and national authorities.

trigger_statement_2.statement:
The second trigger T2, activates full range of early actions: 

T2 is based on epidemiological and surveillance data. 

Based on this background, T2 may be triggered by: 
1. A spike in AWD/ADD CBS true signals, such as:  
a. Doubling of alert thresholds – from at least 5 to at least 10 signals within one week. 
2. Confidential information from the MoH indicating a rise in AWD/ADD cases  
3. MoH confirmation of AWD/Cholera
thresholds: Doubling of AWD/ADD CBS true signals from at least 5 to at least 10 signals within one week
Confidential information from Ministry of Health indicating a rise in AWD/ADD cases
Ministry of Health confirmation of AWD/Cholera cases
trigger_statement_2.source_authority: Somali Red Crescent Society (SRCS) CBS system, Ministry of Health (MoH), SRCS Emergency Operations Centre (EoC)
trigger_statement_2.lead_time: 10 days from T2 activation to implementation of early actions
trigger_statement_2.geographic_scope: Selected priority locations in Somalia with CBS implementation, including Garowe and Bosaso (Puntland), Borama and Burao districts (Somaliland)
trigger_statement_2.preliminary_actions: Full range of early actions including hygiene promotion, distribution of ORS and Zinc, Aqua Tabs distribution, referrals, and risk communication and community engagement (RCCE). Continuous epidemiological monitoring and outbreak investigations guide further actions.

trigger_mechanism.description: The Heatwave simplified Early Action Protocol (sEAP) for Albania is triggered based on a probabilistic forecast from ECMWF. The trigger activates if there is at least a 50% probability of experiencing at least 3 consecutive days in Tirana where both the maximum and minimum temperatures exceed the 95th percentile of historical monthly maximum and minimum temperatures for June to September (based on data from 2000 to 2024). Once triggered in Tirana, the activation automatically applies to the cities of Elbasan and Berat due to identical temperature patterns. The trigger is monitored daily by the Albanian Institute of Geoscience (IGEO) and shared with the Albanian Red Cross and Civil Protection partners during the summer season. The lead time for activation is 5 days. There is no mention of a stop or deactivation mechanism in the document.

trigger_statement_1.statement: The Heatwave sEAP is triggered in Tirana, Elbasan, and Berat if, with a probability of 50% according to ECMWF, there are at least 3 consecutive days in Tirana where the expected maximum and minimum temperatures are both higher than the 95th percentile of the monthly historical maximum and minimum temperatures of the months of June-September, based on data from 2000 to 2024.
thresholds: 50% probability according to ECMWF
At least 3 consecutive days in Tirana
Expected maximum temperature higher than the 95th percentile of monthly historical maximum temperatures for June-September (2000-2024)
Expected minimum temperature higher than the 95th percentile of monthly historical minimum temperatures for June-September (2000-2024)
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: ECMWF (European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts), monitored by Albanian Institute of Geoscience (IGEO)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Cities of Tirana, Elbasan, and Berat, Albania
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Once triggered, early action activities are implemented in all three cities. The trigger status is shared daily with the Albanian Red Cross and Civil Protection partners during the summer season (June-September). Early actions include multi-purpose cash distribution to vulnerable populations, health and care interventions such as operating a Red Cross green line for heatwave information, training volunteers, distributing educational materials, and conducting proactive remote check calls to vulnerable households.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP trigger mechanism is a single-trigger system based on meteorological forecasts from the ECMWF ensemble predicting cold wave conditions at Zahle. Activation occurs when the median ensemble member forecasts a daily maximum temperature below 2°C with a 7-day lead time. There is a stop mechanism that deactivates the intervention if the forecast with a 5-day lead time no longer meets the threshold. The period between -7 and -5 days is used for preparatory actions and monitoring, with final confirmation at -5 days before full activation.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: If the median ensemble member of the ECMWF ensemble indicates that the daily maximum temperature at Zahle is less than 2°C with a lead time of 5 days, the intervention is stopped to prevent unnecessary expenditure and ensure effective resource allocation.

trigger_statement_1.statement:
The activation of early actions within this simplified EAP will be initiated when the following conditions are met:
Release of funds:
"When the median ensemble member of the ECMWF ensemble indicates that the daily maximum temperature at Zahle is projected to be less than 2°C, with a lead time of 7 days."
Stop mechanism:
“When the median ensemble member of the ECMWF ensemble indicates that the daily maximum temperature at Zahle is less than 2 oC with a lead time of 5 days”.
thresholds: Median ensemble member of ECMWF forecasts daily maximum temperature at Zahle below 2°C with a lead time of 7 days
Median ensemble member of ECMWF forecasts daily maximum temperature at Zahle below 2°C with a lead time of 5 days (stop mechanism)
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: ECMWF (European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts)
trigger_statement_1.lead_time: 7 days for activation, 5 days for stop mechanism
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Zahle, Lebanon
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Between -7 and -5 days: convene expert committee, liaise with government counterparts, activate volunteers; at -5 days: preparatory actions such as volunteer refreshers can be halted if stop condition is met; final selection of intervention areas based on more accurate forecast at 5 days lead time.

trigger_mechanism.description: The trigger system for dengue early action in Sri Lanka is based on two main scenarios: meteorological forecasts and epidemiological surveillance data. A readiness trigger is activated when the Meteorological Department forecasts average rainfall exceeding 100mm in the Western Province, which typically precedes dengue outbreaks by 2 to 4 weeks. Early action triggers are activated based on weekly dengue case counts reported by the National Dengue Control Unit (NDCU), either when weekly caseload exceeds 1,500 cases during specific months or when caseload in target districts exceeds 1.5 times their average caseload. The triggers are dual-trigger and multi-stage in nature, with readiness trigger preceding early action triggers. There is no explicit stop or deactivation mechanism described in the document.

trigger_statement_1.statement:
The trigger for intervention is defined based on two scenarios: weekly epidemiological reports issued by the National Dengue Control Unit (NDCU) and meteorological predictions.

Readiness Trigger:
The Meteorological Department forecasts average rainfall exceeding 100mm in the Western Province. (There is typically a lag time of two to four weeks between heavy rainfall and subsequent dengue outbreaks.)
Sri Lanka experiences two monsoon seasons, with the Southwest monsoon bringing the highest rainfall, particularly in the Colombo, Kalutara, and Gampaha districts. When average rainfall exceeds 100mm, it creates favorable conditions for dengue outbreaks in the Western Province, which can then spread to Jaffna and Kandy districts due to human movement.

Early Action Triggers:
The trigger is activated under the following conditions:
• Weekly caseload exceeding 1,500 cases in the months of May, June, July and December, and January.
OR
• If the caseload in the target districts exceeds 1.5 times higher than their average caseload.
This trigger point was established based on the average number of confirmed cases reported to the Ministry of Health (MoH) by the National Dengue Control Unit (NDCU) through the district-wise weekly epidemiological reports (WER). Although this trigger is based on national figures, the majority of the contributions typically come from the five high-risk districts, which account for nearly 50% of the national caseload (see Figure 2). Furthermore, Sri Lanka is a relatively small island, and the geographic areas of these five districts are limited in size.
thresholds: Meteorological Department forecasts average rainfall exceeding 100mm in the Western Province
Weekly dengue caseload exceeding 1,500 cases in May, June, July, December, and January
Weekly dengue caseload in target districts exceeds 1.5 times their average caseload
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: National Dengue Control Unit (NDCU), Meteorological Department, Ministry of Health (MoH)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Western Province (Colombo, Kalutara, Gampaha districts), with spread potential to Jaffna and Kandy districts
trigger_statement_1.condition_dependency: Early action triggers depend on the readiness trigger indicating favorable meteorological conditions; readiness trigger precedes early action triggers
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions:
Triggered by readiness trigger: elimination of mosquito breeding sites at community level targeting high-risk settings (construction sites, schools, religious places), logistical support for dengue response teams at MOH level with transport, equipment, and stationery; mass/social media mobilization to eliminate breeding sites; empowering children in school circles to lead and monitor dengue response.
Triggered by early action trigger: intensified elimination of mosquito breeding sites, house-to-house surveillance campaigns before and after rainy season, volunteer deployments in hospitals, distribution of IEC materials to patients and families, training households on water container management, volunteer door-to-door visits for community mobilization, continuous monitoring and clean-up campaigns in public places.

trigger_mechanism.description: The trigger mechanism for this simplified Early Action Protocol (EAP) for Tropical Cyclones in Fiji is a dual-stage system based on forecast lead times from the Regional Specialized Meteorological Centre (RSMC) in Nadi. The first stage is a readiness trigger activated if any point in the 120-hour (5-day) unofficial forecast meets the trigger conditions, providing early warning for preparedness activities. The second stage is an activation trigger based on the official 72-hour forecast, which initiates the release of funds, dissemination of early warnings, and distribution of early action items. The triggers are based on cyclone category and proximity to Fiji. Notifications are automated and coordinated through NDMO and OCHA. There is no mention of a stop or deactivation mechanism.

trigger_statement_1.statement:
This simplified EAP will be triggered by a tropical cyclone that is forecasted by the Regional Specialized Meteorological Centre (RSMC) in Nadi to be a:
• Category11 4 or 5 while within 250 km of Fiji, or
• Category 3, 4, or 5 while making landfall in Fiji
thresholds: Category 4 or 5 cyclone within 250 km of Fiji
Category 3, 4, or 5 cyclone making landfall in Fiji
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Regional Specialized Meteorological Centre (RSMC) in Nadi, operated by Fiji Meteorological Services (FMS)
trigger_statement_1.lead_time: Two stages: readiness trigger at 120 hours (5 days) lead time based on unofficial forecast; activation trigger at 72 hours (3 days) lead time based on official forecast
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Fiji national level coverage, with focus on coastal low-lying areas and other vulnerable locations determined by projected cyclone pathway
trigger_statement_1.condition_dependency: The activation trigger (72 hours lead time) is conditional on the readiness trigger (120 hours lead time) being met first
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: At readiness trigger (120 hours lead time): Inform relevant branches to prepare, activate internal fund release processes, preposition funds and resources, notify logistics providers, move staff and volunteers to likely affected divisions, check pre-positioned items, conduct stakeholder coordination meetings, confirm target communities and households based on Fiji Mets updates. At activation trigger (72 hours lead time): Distribute early action items to identified communities, disseminate early warning messages via social and mainstream media, conduct door-to-door messaging, disseminate health messages, distribute safe shelter kits (SSKs), jerry cans, soap, and livelihood items to selected households, collect feedback from target communities and households.

trigger_mechanism.description: The Early Action Protocol (EAP) for floods in Tanzania is activated based on a single scientifically defined trigger using a 5-day Severe Weather Impact-Based Forecast from the Tanzania Meteorological Authority (TMA). Activation occurs when specific rainfall warning thresholds are met across multiple administrative regions and river basins for consecutive days, with additional advisory warnings on other days. A stop mechanism exists to avoid full activation if the forecast is downgraded below the severe threshold three or more days before the event.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: Full activation is avoided if the forecast is downgraded below the severe threshold three or more days before the event. In such cases, preparedness and early warning activities continue in areas where alerts remain.

trigger_statement_1.statement:
The EAP is triggered when the following conditions are met:
• A severe rainfall warning (orange) or major warning (red) is issued in over 10 administrative regions across more than three river basins, lasting at least two consecutive days.
• At least one advisory-level warning (yellow) is present on any of the remaining days within the five-day forecast.
thresholds: A severe rainfall warning (orange) or major warning (red) is issued in over 10 administrative regions across more than three river basins, lasting at least two consecutive days
At least one advisory-level warning (yellow) is present on any of the remaining days within the five-day forecast
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Tanzania Meteorological Authority (TMA)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Tanzania, specifically over 10 administrative regions across more than three river basins
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Once the trigger is met, the Anticipatory Action Coordinator at the Tanzania Red Cross Society initiates internal communication with relevant departments and partners, informs senior leadership, disaster management officials, finance and logistics units, and notifies the IFRC and government disaster management bodies. Early actions include mobilizing teams, deploying volunteers, sensitizing communities, and pre-positioning emergency supplies.

trigger_mechanism.description: The Early Action Protocol (EAP) trigger system is based on combined meteorological and hydrological indicators including cumulative monthly rainfall exceeding historical averages, forecast alerts from the Fanfar system, water level measurements at hydrometric beacons, and the ECMWF Extreme Forecast Index (EFI) for heavy rainfall. The trigger activates when specific thresholds for these indicators are met simultaneously in targeted river basins. The system uses a multi-parameter conditional trigger combining rainfall, forecast alerts, and water levels. There is no mandatory stop mechanism, but a shutdown mechanism may be considered if the early action timeframe exceeds four days to avoid confusion if forecasts change.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: The simplified EAP does not require a stop mechanism; however, if the early action timeframe is longer than four days, a deadline to stop early action activities may be considered if forecasts change, to prevent confusion in communities (e.g., stopping evacuations if cyclone path changes).

trigger_statement_1.statement: This EAP will be triggered if cumulative monthly rainfall is recorded in the Agneby basin (Agboville) above the 1991-2020 reference average, that the Fanfar forecast is on orange alert and that the beacon is in orange with a water level of 695 cm, a significant threshold, with a significant threshold of 695 cm, with a significant threshold of 695 cm, with a significant threshold of 695 cm, with a significant threshold of 695 cm, with a significant threshold of 695 cm, with a significant threshold of 695 cm, with a significant threshold of 5 days. Or, if monthly rainfall is recorded above the 1991-2020 reference average, Fanfar's forecast is on orange alert and the beacon is orange with a water level of 665 cm, a significant threshold, and the EFI 0.8 index forecasts rainfall greater than or equal to 92 mm in the following 5 days, then the alert for the N'Zi was triggered.
thresholds: Cumulative monthly rainfall above the 1991-2020 reference average in the Agneby basin (Agboville)
Fanfar forecast on orange alert
Beacon water level in orange alert at 695 cm (significant threshold)
Beacon water level in orange alert at 665 cm (significant threshold)
ECMWF Extreme Forecast Index (EFI) greater than or equal to 0.8 forecasting rainfall ≥ 92 mm in next 5 days
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Fanfar forecast system, National Meteorological Directorate, Directorate of Hydrology, ECMWF (European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Agneby basin (Agboville) and N'Zi basin (Dimbokro), Côte d'Ivoire
trigger_statement_1.condition_dependency: Trigger requires cumulative rainfall above historical average AND Fanfar forecast orange alert AND beacon water level at specified thresholds; for N'Zi basin, additionally requires EFI index forecast of heavy rainfall
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Monitoring of water levels using hydrometric stations; monitoring beacon color codes; flood forecast development with Fanfar; heavy rainfall forecast with ECMWF; field teams monitor beacons and water levels; early warning dissemination and preparation of vulnerable communities

trigger_mechanism.description: The trigger mechanism is a single-trigger system activated by official institutions issuing documents (Act, Bulletin, or Early Alert) indicating that a massive forced displacement caused by armed conflict has occurred or is imminent in specified departments of the Colombian Pacific region. The trigger is based on reaching or exceeding predefined thresholds of displaced persons per department. Early actions begin once displaced persons arrive at receiving municipalities, with an estimated lead time of 3 to 5 days after activation. There is no explicit stop or deactivation mechanism described.

trigger_statement_1.statement:
La activación de este sEAP se cumplirá cuando la institución correspondiente (Comité de Justicia Transicional, OCHA o la Defensoría del Pueblo) emita uno de los respectivos documentos oficiales o activadores: Acta, Boletín o Alerta Temprana, en el que se indique que ha ocurrido un desplazamiento forzado masivo causado por el conflicto armado, o el riesgo de ocurrencia es inminente, en uno o más de los municipios de los departamentos que constituyen la región Pacífico colombiana (Chocó, Valle del Cauca, Cauca o Nariño) que alcance (o pueda alcanzar) el umbral establecido en número de víctimas desplazadas por departamento.

Umbral por departamento:
Chocó: 1,290 personas
Cauca: 1,696 personas
Nariño: 3,040 personas
Valle del Cauca: 2,078 personas

Los umbrales definidos basados en el registro inicial del número de personas desplazadas forzadamente en cada departamento son críticos, no solo porque superan ampliamente las cifras de otros eventos de desplazamiento, sino también porque, al ser tan altos en número, exceden la capacidad de respuesta de las autoridades locales y también la capacidad y recursos de los actores humanitarios debido a su magnitud.

En los departamentos donde la activación del sEAP tiene umbrales inferiores al objetivo mínimo de 2,000 personas (Cauca y Chocó), esto ocurre porque los municipios tienen menor densidad poblacional, por lo que se planea incluir en las acciones tempranas a las comunidades anfitrionas en el municipio receptor, para mitigar posibles impactos causados por "discriminación" hacia las personas desplazadas porque ellas reciben atención y servicios, pero los locales, que también ven reducidos sus recursos y sienten el impacto en su seguridad e integridad, no disfrutan de las mismas oportunidades.
trigger_statement_1.statement_english:
The activation of this sEAP will be met when the corresponding institution (Transitional Justice Committee, OCHA or the Ombudsman's Office) issues one of the respective official or activating documents: Act, Bulletin or Early Alert, indicating that a massive forced displacement caused by armed conflict has occurred, or the risk of occurrence is imminent, in one or more municipalities of the departments constituting the Colombian Pacific region (Chocó, Valle del Cauca, Cauca or Nariño) that reaches (or may reach) the threshold established in number of displaced victims per department.

Threshold by department:
Chocó: 1,290 people
Cauca: 1,696 people
Nariño: 3,040 people
Valle del Cauca: 2,078 people

The thresholds defined based on the initial registration of forcibly displaced persons in each department are critical, not only because they far exceed figures for other displacement events, but also because, being so high in number, they exceed the response capacity of local authorities and humanitarian actors due to their magnitude.

In departments where the sEAP activation thresholds are below the minimum target of 2,000 people (Cauca and Chocó), this is because municipalities have lower population density, so early actions plan to include host communities in the receiving municipality to mitigate possible impacts caused by "discrimination" against displaced persons who receive care and services, while locals, who also see their resources reduced and feel impacts on their security and integrity, do not enjoy the same opportunities.
thresholds: Chocó: 1,290 displaced persons
Cauca: 1,696 displaced persons
Nariño: 3,040 displaced persons
Valle del Cauca: 2,078 displaced persons
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Transitional Justice Committee, OCHA, Ombudsman's Office
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Colombian Pacific region departments: Chocó, Valle del Cauca, Cauca, Nariño
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Early actions begin once displaced persons arrive at receiving municipalities (temporary locations such as parks, stadiums, schools). The Colombian Red Cross coordinates with local authorities to provide support including health, protection, gender and inclusion, and WASH sectors. Early actions last approximately 30 days aiming to mitigate humanitarian impacts and support recovery.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP trigger mechanism consists of three distinct triggers based on climate and agricultural forecasts. Trigger 0 is a pre-trigger based on ENSO (Nino3.4 index) forecast in July, which initiates pre-actions. Trigger 1 is based on the ECMWF SEAS5 seasonal forecast in October predicting below-average precipitation with a probability threshold, activating the first set of early actions. Trigger 2 occurs in March-April based on Ministry of Agriculture crop loss projections and Zambia Meteorological Department rainfall measurements, activating a second set of early actions. These triggers operate independently without conditional dependencies between them. A stop mechanism exists to halt activation if risk declines during the lead time.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: If the forecasted risk declines (e.g., probability drops below 40% by day 10 of the 25-day lead time), an Emergency Operations Meeting is convened by the Zambia Red Cross Society Disaster Management Manager to recommend stopping the activation. If stopped, pre-purchased non-food items are stored for future use and planned later-phase activities such as cash transfers are canceled.

trigger_statement_1.statement: Trigger 0. When the ECMWF issues in July an NDJ average forecast of a Nino3.4 index>=0.5K, the pre-trigger is reached and the pre-actions will be started.
thresholds: Nino3.4 index equal or greater than 0.5K in NDJ average forecast issued in July
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF)
trigger_statement_1.lead_time: 3 months (forecast issued in July for NDJ period)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Zambia
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Pre-actions are started upon reaching this pre-trigger.

trigger_statement_2.statement: Trigger 1. When the ECMWF SEAS5 seasonal forecast issued in October forecasts a below average precipitation (with 45% and above probability of the ‘below average’ tercile), the first trigger is reached and the first set of funded early actions will be implemented in anticipation of a failed rainy season.
thresholds: Below average precipitation forecast
At least 45% probability of below average precipitation tercile
Forecast issued in October
trigger_statement_2.source_authority: European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF) SEAS5 seasonal forecast
trigger_statement_2.lead_time: 3 months (forecast issued in October for upcoming rainy season)
trigger_statement_2.geographic_scope: Zambia
trigger_statement_2.condition_dependency: No dependency on Trigger 0; can activate independently.
trigger_statement_2.preliminary_actions: First set of funded early actions implemented in anticipation of failed rainy season.

trigger_statement_3.statement: Trigger 2. When the Ministry of Agriculture CFSI in March-April projects 40% and above losses in the current season and ZMD calculates more than 21 days of no rain higher than 1mm during the period DJFM, the second set of funded early actions will be implemented in anticipation of declining food and economic security.
thresholds: Ministry of Agriculture Crop Forecast Survey Index (CFSI) projects 40% or greater crop losses
More than 21 consecutive days of no rain greater than 1mm during December to March (DJFM)
trigger_statement_3.source_authority: Ministry of Agriculture Crop Forecast Survey Index (CFSI) and Zambia Meteorological Department (ZMD)
trigger_statement_3.lead_time: 0-1 month (March-April projections and rainfall monitoring during DJFM)
trigger_statement_3.condition_dependency: Can activate independently of Trigger 0 and Trigger 1; if only Trigger 2 is met, only second set of early actions are implemented.
trigger_statement_3.preliminary_actions: Second set of funded early actions implemented in anticipation of declining food and economic security.

trigger_mechanism.description: The Early Action Protocol (EAP) for riverine floods in Mali is activated based on hydrological forecasts and water level measurements exceeding a 5-year return period threshold at key monitoring stations along the Niger and Senegal Rivers. Once this threshold is reached, early actions are triggered 4 to 8 days before the expected peak flooding to protect vulnerable populations. The system includes a stop/deactivation mechanism if forecasts indicate flood levels will not reach the critical threshold within three days.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: A deactivation mechanism is applied if forecasts indicate that flood levels will not reach the critical threshold within three days, ensuring efficient resource allocation.

trigger_statement_1.statement: Le PAE est déclenché lorsque la Direction Nationale de l'Hydraulique (DNH) et Mali Météo émettent une prévision d'inondation correspondant à une période de retour de 5 ans. Une fois ce seuil atteint, les actions précoces sont initiées 4 à 8 jours avant le pic d'inondation attendu.
trigger_statement_1.statement_english: The EAP is triggered when the National Directorate of Hydraulics (DNH) and Mali Météo issue a 5-year return period flood forecast. Once this threshold is reached, early actions are initiated 4 to 8 days before the expected peak flooding.
thresholds: Flood forecast corresponding to a 5-year return period
Water levels exceeding the 5-year return period threshold at key monitoring stations
Flood activation thresholds ranging from 370 cm in Bamako to 859 cm in Kayes
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: National Directorate of Hydraulics (DNH) and Mali Météo
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Flood-prone regions along the Niger and Senegal Rivers, including Mopti, Ségou, Timbuktu, Gao, Kayes, and Bamako in Mali
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Community awareness campaigns, evacuation planning and support, distribution of sandbags, reinforcement of dikes, pre-positioning of emergency supplies, sanitation and hygiene interventions, livelihood protection measures.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP activation is based on a dual-trigger system: first, a climatic trigger with a 2-month lead time based on flooding or heavy rainfall thresholds; second, a surveillance trigger with a 5-day lead time triggered only if the climatic trigger was activated in the last three months and based on epidemiological alerts and confirmed cases. The surveillance trigger depends conditionally on the climatic trigger. There is a stop/deactivation mechanism for both triggers based on absence of confirmed cholera cases within specified timeframes.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: For the Climatic Trigger (Trigger 1), if no cholera case is confirmed by the Ministry of Health within two months of activation, early action activities are gradually phased out. For the Surveillance Trigger (Trigger 2), if the Ministry of Health completes its outbreak investigation and finds no confirmed cholera cases, early action measures are discontinued. If cholera is confirmed, the response transitions to a contingency plan under a different financing mechanism.

trigger_statement_1.statement: Climatic Trigger (Trigger 1) • Threshold: Activation occurs when there is flooding affecting more than 2,000 people or when heavy rainfall (≥50mm/day for four consecutive days) is recorded. • Lead Time: Two months from the start of the flood or heavy rainfall period. • Source of Data: Information is collected through the National Meteorological Directorate, the Community-Based Early Warning System (SCAP), and reports from CRC volunteers and local authorities.
thresholds: Flooding affecting more than 2,000 people
Heavy rainfall of at least 50 mm per day for four consecutive days
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: National Meteorological Directorate, Community-Based Early Warning System (SCAP), CRC volunteers and local authorities
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: 56 high-risk districts in Cameroon, mainly in Littoral, Southwest, and Center regions
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: If community-based surveillance (CBS) is not active in the district: train volunteers and supervisors on CBS and establish the intervention. If CBS is active: provide additional training to intensify CBS activities. Strengthen case surveillance and reporting (CBS). Train healthcare personnel in Infection Prevention and Control (IPC) and cholera case management. Conduct rapid vulnerability assessments including Protection, Gender, and Inclusion aspects. Establish or strengthen hygiene committees. Train volunteers and supervisors in disinfection, awareness campaigns, water point sanitation, use of water purifiers, and setup of oral rehydration points. Deploy volunteers to supply handwashing stations. Conduct coordination meetings and pre-position WASH and health supplies.

trigger_statement_2.statement: Surveillance-Based Trigger (Trigger 2) • Threshold: Triggered when a district where Trigger 1 was activated in the last three months reports: • At least five community alert cases of Acute Watery Diarrhea (AWD) within the same district in a single week. • At least five suspected cholera cases in the same district in a single week, reported by the Ministry of Health (MoH). • At least one confirmed cholera case in a neighboring district or cross-border area, as validated by the MoH. • Lead Time: Five days after detecting one of the above criteria. • Source of Data: MoH surveillance reports, situation reports (SitRep), and CRC community-based surveillance.
thresholds: At least five community alert cases of Acute Watery Diarrhea (AWD) within the same district in a single week
At least five suspected cholera cases in the same district in a single week, reported by the Ministry of Health
At least one confirmed cholera case in a neighboring district or cross-border area, validated by the Ministry of Health
trigger_statement_2.source_authority: Ministry of Health surveillance reports, situation reports (SitRep), CRC community-based surveillance
trigger_statement_2.geographic_scope: Districts where Climatic Trigger was activated in the last three months, including neighboring districts and cross-border areas
trigger_statement_2.condition_dependency: Trigger 2 activation is conditional on Trigger 1 having been activated in the same district within the last three months
trigger_statement_2.preliminary_actions: Distribute Oral Rehydration Salts (ORS) to notified alert cases and refer them to healthcare facilities for proper case management. Distribute water purifiers for household use. Deploy volunteers to supply handwashing stations. Conduct WASH disinfection in households (including patient beds, toilets, kitchens) and public spaces (schools, markets, public services) where suspected cases have been reported. Sanitize contaminated water points.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP uses a dual-trigger mechanism based on weather forecasts issued by the National Directorate for Meteorology and Geophysics (DNMG) in Timor-Leste. Trigger 1 (Preparedness phase) activates when an orange warning (special attention) is forecasted for more than three target municipalities for three consecutive days within a 5-day forecast period, indicating expected cumulative rainfall of 150 mm or more. Trigger 2 (Activation phase) activates when a red warning (extreme rain) is forecasted for any target municipality for two consecutive days within a 3-day forecast period, indicating expected cumulative rainfall of more than 200 mm in 72 hours. Evacuation early action under Trigger 2 is only activated at 24 hours lead time. The triggers are conditional in sequence: Trigger 1 precedes Trigger 2. There is no explicit stop or deactivation mechanism described.

trigger_statement_1.statement:
Trigger 1 – Preparedness phase (5 days lead time)
The first trigger will be reached when a 5-day weather forecast from DNMG indicates an orange warning (special attention) in more than three target municipalities for three consecutive days or more in the next 5 days period. This means, the relevant pre-agreed preparedness phase activities will commence in those targeted municipalities expected to receive a cumulative rainfall total of 150 mm or more during the forecasted period of heavy rainfall in the next 5 days.
thresholds: Orange warning (special attention) indicating rainfall intensity of 10-20 mm/hr or 50-100 mm/day
Orange warning in more than three target municipalities
