Orange warning sustained for three consecutive days or more within a 5-day forecast period
Expected cumulative rainfall total of 150 mm or more during the forecasted period
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: National Directorate for Meteorology and Geophysics (DNMG)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Target municipalities of Manatuto, Viqueque, Manufahi, Covalima, and Oecusse in Timor-Leste
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Commencement of relevant pre-agreed preparedness phase activities in targeted municipalities

trigger_statement_2.statement:
Trigger 2 – Activation phase (3 days lead time)
The second trigger will be reached when a 3-day weather forecast from DNMG issues a red warning (extreme rain) in any of the target municipalities for two consecutive days. This means all the relevant pre-agreed early actions will be triggered in the respective municipalities that are likely to receive rainfall with a cumulative total of more than 200mm in next 72 hours. The evacuation early action will only be triggered at the 24-hour lead time.
thresholds: Red warning (alert) indicating rainfall intensity of more than 20 mm/hr or daily total of more than 100 mm
Red warning issued in any target municipality
Red warning sustained for two consecutive days within a 3-day forecast period
Expected cumulative rainfall total of more than 200 mm in next 72 hours
Evacuation early action triggered only at 24-hour lead time
trigger_statement_2.source_authority: National Directorate for Meteorology and Geophysics (DNMG)
trigger_statement_2.lead_time: 3 days for activation of early actions; 24 hours for evacuation early action
trigger_statement_2.geographic_scope: Target municipalities of Manatuto, Viqueque, Manufahi, Covalima, and Oecusse in Timor-Leste
trigger_statement_2.condition_dependency: Trigger 2 activation depends on forecasted red warning after Trigger 1 preparedness phase
trigger_statement_2.preliminary_actions: Trigger 2 leads to activation of all relevant pre-agreed early actions including evacuation of vulnerable people

trigger_mechanism.description: The Early Action Protocol (EAP) for floods in Indonesia uses a probabilistic rainfall forecast-based trigger system. Early actions are activated based on rainfall intensity forecasts and water level data, with thresholds refined by historical flood data and a five-year return period analysis. The trigger system includes a pre-activation stage based on lower rainfall thresholds and probability, followed by activation when higher thresholds and probabilities are met. Activation decisions are made by the Indonesian Red Cross National Headquarters based on forecasts from BMKG and BNPB's Prevention Dashboard. The system monitors multiple data sources including rainfall forecasts, river water levels, and radar observations. There is no explicit stop or deactivation mechanism described.

trigger_statement_1.statement: BMKG defines heavy rainfall as total daily rainfall exceeding 50 mm which serves as the initial threshold for determining potential flood risks. This threshold for early action is further refined based on a five-year return period analysis of daily rainfall in four watersheds: Bengawan Solo, Babura, Barito, and Mahakam. The analysis reveals that floods are often triggered by rainfall exceeding 100 mm, with an 80% confidence level. Consequently, a threshold of 80 mm is set as the trigger for early action, based on technical consultations with the Indonesian Red Cross and historical flood data, which demonstrate the significant impacts on infrastructure and lives when rainfall exceeds this value. The trigger is applicable nation-wide. PMI NHQ will make the activation decision based on BMKG forecasts or BNPB’s Prevention Dashboard as follows: Condition 1: BMKG has issued forecast information for rainfall intensity exceeding 100mm in 24 hours with a probability of 80%, which can be observed through the following links: for rainfall: https://web.meteo.bmkg.go.id/id/model-prediksi-cuaca/nwp-wrf/hujan/daily-precipitation/wrf-precipitation-daily-indonesia for probability: https://web.meteo.bmkg.go.id/id/model-prediksi-cuaca/ensemble-wrf/probability-of-20-mm-hour-precipitation The forecast information is available for up to 3 (three) days ahead. Or Condition 2: BNPB, through the Dashboard Pencegahan, provides information on rainfall exceeding the threshold of 80 mm/day in a specific area, which can be accessed through the following link: https://dashboardpencegahan.bnpb.go.id/ The forecast information is available for up to 2 days ahead.
thresholds: Total daily rainfall exceeding 50 mm (initial threshold for flood risk)
Rainfall exceeding 100 mm in 24 hours with 80% probability (BMKG forecast)
Rainfall exceeding 80 mm/day (BNPB Prevention Dashboard)
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: BMKG (Indonesian Meteorology, Climatology, and Geophysics Agency), BNPB (National Disaster Management Agency)
trigger_statement_1.lead_time: Up to 3 days ahead (BMKG forecast), up to 2 days ahead (BNPB Dashboard)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Nation-wide Indonesia
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Activation decision by PMI NHQ based on forecasts; early actions are activated once conditions are met.

trigger_statement_2.statement: "Pre-activation" is carried out by utilizing forecast information on rainfall intensity exceeding 50mm in 6 hours with a probability of over 60% during the 6 days prior to the peak, which can be observed through the following link: https://web.meteo.bmkg.go.id/id/model-prediksi-cuaca/nwp-parameter-cuaca/probabilistic-forecast/precipitation-probability-50-mm-6-hourly Given the limitations of Indonesia's early warning system in providing rainfall data in millimeters and the probability, Indonesia Red Cross will draw on a combination of modalities to trigger flood Early Actions. This includes BMKG’s probabilistic forecasts, regularly monitored by Indonesia Red Cross to estimate rainfall accumulation exceeding thresholds, and river water level data validated through SIHKA PUPR and the Prevention Dashboard. Although the Prevention Dashboard is not fully operational, it informs rainfall locations with 50mm precipitation based on hourly radar observations, with early warnings disseminated via Telegram. Additionally, Indonesia Red Cross monitors water levels at risk areas through PUPR’s POS EWS stations, categorized as Waspada (Alert), Siaga (Standby), or Awas (Warning), with updates also shared through Telegram.
thresholds: Rainfall intensity exceeding 50 mm in 6 hours with over 60% probability during the 6 days prior to peak
River water level monitoring categorized as Alert (Waspada), Standby (Siaga), or Warning (Awas)
trigger_statement_2.source_authority: BMKG (Indonesian Meteorology, Climatology, and Geophysics Agency), SIHKA PUPR (Public Works and Housing Ministry), BNPB Prevention Dashboard
trigger_statement_2.lead_time: 6 days prior to peak (pre-activation), hourly updates for water levels
trigger_statement_2.geographic_scope: Nation-wide Indonesia, with focus on flood-prone watersheds and risk areas
trigger_statement_2.condition_dependency: Pre-activation stage precedes full activation based on higher rainfall thresholds
trigger_statement_2.preliminary_actions: Pre-activation activities include monitoring forecasts and water levels, dissemination of early warnings via Telegram, and preparation for early action implementation.

trigger_mechanism.description: The Early Action Protocol (EAP) uses a dual-trigger system where the first trigger is a forecast probability of a tropical storm or hurricane entering a designated emergency watch area, and the second trigger is a forecast of extreme rainfall exceeding a specified threshold. Trigger 1 must be met before Trigger 2 can activate the EAP. Early actions without cost can be taken upon meeting Trigger 1, while Trigger 2 activates the full EAP and early actions.

trigger_statement_1.statement:
Trigger 1:
The National Hurricane Center (NHC) issues a greater than 60% chance of a tropical storm or hurricane moving into the General Directorate of the Hazards and Natural Resources Observatory (DGOA) "emergency stage watch area" for the next 7 days.
thresholds: Greater than 60% chance of a tropical storm or hurricane entering the DGOA emergency stage watch area within the next 7 days
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: U.S. National Hurricane Center (NHC)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: DGOA emergency stage watch area in El Salvador
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Early actions that do not require cost for the EAP can be carried out when this trigger is met

trigger_statement_2.statement:
Trigger 2:
DGOA forecast of extreme rainfall, associated with a tropical storm or hurricane, exceeding 200 mm accumulated for a 3-day horizon in the months of May through November.
thresholds: Accumulated rainfall forecast exceeding 200 mm over a 3-day period
Forecast period: May through November
trigger_statement_2.source_authority: General Directorate of the Hazards and Natural Resources Observatory (DGOA)
trigger_statement_2.geographic_scope: High-risk areas in El Salvador exposed to tropical cyclones
trigger_statement_2.condition_dependency: Trigger 2 activation is conditional on Trigger 1 being fulfilled first
trigger_statement_2.preliminary_actions: This trigger activates the EAP and initiates the full early actions

trigger_mechanism.description: The trigger system is a single-trigger mechanism activated when specific meteorological and fire risk conditions are met, indicating a high probability of wildfire impact on vulnerable communities. The trigger requires that ignition probability, wind speed, and relative humidity thresholds are simultaneously met or exceeded. There is a stop mechanism that reassesses conditions 3 days after the initial trigger to confirm if thresholds are still met or if the risk has decreased, allowing deactivation.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: An updated forecast 3 days after receiving the trigger forecast is used to confirm if conditions remain above thresholds or if the probability of reaching the defined thresholds has decreased, allowing for stopping or deactivation of the trigger.

trigger_statement_1.statement:
Trigger: Activation will be declared when the "Red Button" condition is reached, an ignition probability equal to or greater than 70%, wind speed equal to or greater than 20 Km/h, relative humidity less than 30% in the threatened territory. With 8 days in advance, this forecast must maintain a high probability that vulnerable communities will be reached.
Stop mechanism: There will be a stop mechanism that will be an updated forecast 3 days after receiving the trigger forecast, to confirm if conditions are still above the thresholds or if they have lowered their probability of reaching the thresholds defined in the trigger.
thresholds: Ignition probability equal to or greater than 70%
Wind speed equal to or greater than 20 Km/h
Relative humidity less than 30% in the threatened territory
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: CONAF (National Forestry Corporation), Red Button forecast system
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: V Region of Chile: Coastal farallón, Intermediate Depression and Cordillera de la Costa; VII Region of Chile: Coastal Zone, Maule Basin and Pre-mountain range
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Monitoring of the fire's advance by CONAF, alerting SENAPRED to decree alerts and evacuations; coordination with Chilean Meteorological Directorate (DMC) and Climate Resilience Research Center of the University of Chile to validate forecast; community engagement to identify potential actions; readiness activities including training volunteers, prepositioning PPE and cash transfers, and awareness raising.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP trigger mechanism is based on forecasted Heat Index (HI) values from the Department of Meteorology & Hydrology (DMH) numerical weather prediction models. The trigger activates when the calculated HI reaches or exceeds specific thresholds for Yangon and Mandalay for at least three consecutive days. A 10-day pre-activation trigger from the Indian Meteorology Department (IMD) serves as an early warning to start preparatory actions. The system includes a stop mechanism that deactivates cash distribution if forecasted or observed HI values fall below thresholds during the activation phase.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: A stop mechanism for high-value early actions (such as cash distribution) is initiated if the forecasted Heat Index thresholds do not hold true for the corresponding forecasted days and/or the observed daily maximum temperature and humidity do not correspond to the respective HI thresholds for Yangon and Mandalay. During activation, if forecasted values fall below predefined thresholds, cash distribution activities stop immediately.

trigger_statement_1.statement: The Simplified EAP will be activated when: Calculated Heat Index (HI) ≥ 62.6 Yangon / 58.2 Mandalay for more or equal than 3 consecutive days (No unit to HI as it refers to Index Value) is forecasted based on DMH´s forecasts. The Trigger system used is a 5-day Numerical Weather Prediction (NWP) product of Department of Meteorology & Hydrology (DMH) forecasts - daily maximum temperature & humidity corresponding to a heat index (HI) of more than 90 percentile values for the summer months (March-May), which is 62.6 for Kaba Aye (Yangon) & 58.2 for Mandalay, for at least three consecutive days, with a lead time of maximum 5 days. The lead time of 5 days includes the 3 days heatwave duration. As parameters can be forecasted maximum 5 days in advance, the HW can be forecasted as early as 2 days and as late as just before the HW onset. In case of sudden changes in the forecast, the activation can be triggered on days –4 and -3. For clarification, please refer to Annex I. The confirmation of trigger will initiate early action activities with the targeted population of the corresponding region, which includes setting up FA posts, with shading places and water stands, Heat Awareness / FA visits including the preparation for the cash assistance. Stop Mechanism 1-day HW A stop mechanism for the high value early actions ((cash)will be initiated if the forecasted HI thresholds doesn’t hold true for the corresponding forecasted days and/or the observed daily maximum temperature and humidity for the given day do not correspond to the respective HI thresholds for Yangon and Mandalay. This means, for the cash activity, all the related activities will be conducted when the trigger is reached, but the cash distribution per se will only be implemented during the forecasted heatwave period with a minimum of 48h lead time. And this will be confirmed only when observed HI value surpasses the thresholds for that day and the forecasted HI values for next two days are also surpassing the thresholds, as DMH NWP are more reliable and accurate for 2-3 days lead time only. So, for continuation of the process and full implementation of the EAP including the cash distribution, forecasts must always confirm thresholds being reached for the consecutive 3 days. During the activation phase, in case the forecasted values fall below the predefined thresholds, any activities related to cash distribution shall stop immediately.
thresholds: Heat Index (HI) ≥ 62.6 for Yangon (Kaba Aye) for at least 3 consecutive days
Heat Index (HI) ≥ 58.2 for Mandalay for at least 3 consecutive days
Heat Index corresponds to more than 90th percentile values for summer months (March-May)
Forecast lead time maximum 5 days including 3 days heatwave duration
Observed HI and forecasted HI for next two days must surpass thresholds for cash distribution continuation
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Department of Meteorology & Hydrology (DMH) Myanmar; Numerical Weather Prediction (NWP) model; Indian Meteorology Department (IMD) for pre-activation
trigger_statement_1.lead_time: Up to 5 days lead time including 3 days heatwave duration; pre-activation trigger 10 days before heatwave onset
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Yangon (Kaba Aye) and Mandalay regions, Myanmar
trigger_statement_1.condition_dependency: The cash distribution is conditional on the forecasted and observed HI thresholds being met for consecutive 3 days; pre-activation trigger from IMD 10 days prior initiates preparatory actions before main trigger confirmation.
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Pre-activation trigger from IMD 10 days before heatwave onset initiates preparatory activities such as heads-up to Executive Committee members, verification of beneficiaries, and setting up First Aid posts. Early action activities upon trigger confirmation include setting up First Aid posts with shading and water stands, Heat Awareness and First Aid visits, and preparation for cash assistance.

trigger_mechanism.description: The simplified Early Action Protocol (sEAP) for heat waves in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, is activated based on a single trigger: the forecast by the National Meteorological Agency (ANAM) of a maximum temperature threshold being exceeded for a specified duration. The trigger is a single condition involving temperature exceeding a defined threshold for consecutive days. The lead time for activation is 4 days before the event. The protocol includes monitoring of forecasts by the Red Cross team and designated focal points within ANAM. There is no mention of a stop or deactivation mechanism.

trigger_statement_1.statement: The simplified PAP is activated if a maximum temperature threshold of 42.4°C for at least three (03) consecutive days is announced by the National Meteorological Agency with a lead time of 4 days compared to the beginning.
thresholds: Maximum temperature of 42.4°C or higher
Duration of at least 3 consecutive days
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: National Meteorological Agency (ANAM)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: City of Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Monitoring of ANAM forecasts by the Disaster Management Coordinator, AA Focal Point and AA Focal Point Assistant at CRBF, supported by two focal points within ANAM. Once the threshold is forecasted, at-risk communities are alerted and awareness campaigns are conducted. Early actions include distribution of WASH and dignity kits, food, solar kits, drinking water, lighting kits, refreshment and cooling kits, and home visits for medical follow-up. These actions can be implemented with lead times ranging from 4 to 0 days depending on the specific action.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP trigger mechanism is a single-trigger system activated based on official meteorological forecasts from IDEAM. Activation occurs when a three-month precipitation forecast shows a 50% probability of below-normal rainfall and the Standardized Precipitation Index (SPI) forecast indicates a moderate drought with values equal to or below -1.4 in the Caribbean and Andean departments of Colombia. There is no mention of a stop or deactivation mechanism.

trigger_statement_1.statement: In accordance with the above, this EAP will be activated when IDEAM reports a precipitation forecast (three months) with a probability of 50% that rainfall will be below normal and that the SPI forecast indicates a moderate drought with values equal or below -1.4, for the same forecasted months, in the departments of the Caribbean and Andean region.
thresholds: 50% probability that rainfall will be below normal for the next three months
Standardized Precipitation Index (SPI) forecast indicates moderate drought with values equal or below -1.4 for the same three months
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Institute of Hydrology, Meteorology and Environmental Studies (IDEAM)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Departments of the Caribbean and Andean regions of Colombia
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Monitoring of drought index, Climate Prediction Bulletin, and SPI forecast reports from IDEAM; readiness activities including design and printing of educational materials, purchase and prepositioning of nutritional blocks and hydro-retainers for agricultural and livestock producers; training and community engagement; coordination with local disaster risk management councils.

trigger_mechanism.description: The Early Action Protocol (EAP) for drought in El Salvador uses a dual-trigger system based on meteorological forecasts issued by the General Directorate of Threat Observatory and Natural Resources (DGOA). Trigger 1 activates when an El Niño event is forecasted with at least 60% probability in region 3.4 for the upcoming 3 to 4 months. Trigger 2 activates when a quarterly precipitation forecast indicates accumulated rainfall during May, June, and July will be below normal (below the 33rd percentile). The triggers are independent but both lead to activation of early actions. The system includes monitoring weather conditions three months in advance and a control mechanism evaluated three months after EAP initiation. No explicit stop or deactivation mechanism is described.

trigger_statement_1.statement: When the General Directorate of Threat Observatory and Natural Resources (DGOA) communicates an El Niño event in region 3.4 for the upcoming 3 or 4 months with a 60% probability, based on the official IRI-CPC forecast until April of year (0) or even earlier in year (-1).
thresholds: El Niño event forecast in region 3.4
60% probability
Forecast horizon of 3 to 4 months
Based on official IRI-CPC forecast until April of the current year or earlier in the previous year
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: General Directorate of Threat Observatory and Natural Resources (DGOA), official IRI-CPC forecast
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Region 3.4 (El Niño region), El Salvador
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Dissemination of drought alerts to at-risk populations in high-risk municipalities; hygiene promotion campaign with key messages on treating dehydration and preventing heatstroke to 2,000 families (10,000 individuals).

trigger_statement_2.statement: When the DGOA has issued a quarterly precipitation forecast indicating that accumulated rainfall during May, June, and July will be below normal (33rd percentile).
thresholds: Quarterly precipitation forecast
Accumulated rainfall during May, June, and July below normal
Below 33rd percentile
trigger_statement_2.source_authority: General Directorate of Threat Observatory and Natural Resources (DGOA)
trigger_statement_2.geographic_scope: El Salvador, specifically the Dry Corridor municipalities
trigger_statement_2.preliminary_actions: Awareness workshops on adaptive practices for households with subsistence agro-livelihoods; unconditional cash transfers tied to training sessions on adaptive practices for subsistence farming and livestock households; distribution of unconditional cash transfers for basic needs; assessment, treatment, and distribution of safe drinking water to 600 families; workshops on appropriate water use and hygiene; installation of community water storage tanks in schools and health centers; distribution of family water purification and hygiene kits; cash transfer satisfaction surveys; monitoring and evaluation of lessons learned.

trigger_mechanism.description: The Early Action Protocol (EAP) for Lesotho Cold Wave is activated based on a single meteorological forecast trigger issued by the Lesotho Meteorological Services (LMS). The trigger requires a forecast of a maximum day temperature of 2°C or less in the highlands for at least two consecutive days, with a maximum lead time of four days before the onset of the cold wave event. Once this trigger is met, early actions such as dissemination of early warning information, distribution of winter clothing to vulnerable herders, and unconditional cash transfers to vulnerable households are implemented. The protocol leverages strong coordination with national and local institutions to implement actions within the lead time. There is no mention of a stop or deactivation mechanism in the document.

trigger_statement_1.statement: The EAP is activated when the Lesotho Meteorological Services (LMS) issues a forecast of 2oC maximum day temperature or less in the highlands for at least two consecutive days with a maximum lead time of four days to the onset.
thresholds: Maximum day temperature forecast of 2°C or less
For at least two consecutive days
Maximum lead time of four days before onset
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Lesotho Meteorological Services (LMS)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Highlands of Lesotho
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Dissemination of last mile early warning information and messages using mass notification systems (megaphones, flags), community early warning systems, and online platforms; distribution of pre-positioned winter clothing packs to 500 most vulnerable herders; unconditional cash transfers to vulnerable households with school-aged children; awareness campaigns and verification of beneficiaries; coordination with national and local institutions to implement early actions within lead time.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP trigger mechanism consists of three distinct trigger statements related to typhoon impact forecasts. The EAP will be activated if any one of the three trigger statements is met 72 hours before the anticipated typhoon landfall. The triggers use probabilistic and forecast model data from the Netherlands Red Cross 510 model (which uses ECMWF data) and PAGASA bulletins. There is no stop mechanism included due to the short 3-day lead time, but alternative funding sources may be considered if activation conditions change after lead time.

trigger_statement_1.statement: Statement 1: This EAP will be activated if 72 hours before the anticipated landfall the 510 model indicates at least three (3) municipalities in a province will have 10 per cent of their houses damaged.
thresholds: At least three municipalities in a province will have 10% of their houses damaged
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Netherlands Red Cross 510 model using ECMWF data
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Provinces in the Philippines with at least three municipalities meeting damage threshold
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: PRC chapters and partners conduct readiness activities including training, simulations, pre-registration of beneficiaries, and pre-agreements with service providers for Shelter Strengthening Kit materials.

trigger_statement_2.statement: Statement 2: This EAP will be activated if 72 hours before the anticipated typhoon landfall the 510 model indicates a minimum 50 per cent likelihood of the typhoon causing complete damage to over 200,000 houses across the country. Additionally, the EAP will be activated under conditions of a 60 per cent likelihood of complete damage to more than 160,000 houses, or a 70 per cent likelihood of complete damage to more than 90,000 houses, or an 80 per cent likelihood of complete damage to more than 50,000 houses.
thresholds: 50% likelihood of complete damage to over 200,000 houses nationwide
60% likelihood of complete damage to more than 160,000 houses
70% likelihood of complete damage to more than 90,000 houses
80% likelihood of complete damage to more than 50,000 houses
trigger_statement_2.source_authority: Netherlands Red Cross 510 model using ECMWF forecast ensemble data
trigger_statement_2.geographic_scope: Nationwide across the Philippines
trigger_statement_2.preliminary_actions: Same readiness activities as for Statement 1; monitoring and verification by PRC AA Technical Working Group.

trigger_statement_3.statement: Statement 3: When PAGASA issues a typhoon bulletin with a predicted forecast that a Tropical Cyclone will reach wind speed of a) 185km/h in Central or Northern Luzon (Region 1) or b) 185 km/h in Eastern Visayas, Bicol or Calabarzon (Region 2) or c) 118 km/h in Caraga or Davao regions 72 hours before the expected landfall (Region 3), then this EAP will be activated.
thresholds: Predicted wind speed of 185 km/h in Central or Northern Luzon (Region 1)
Predicted wind speed of 185 km/h in Eastern Visayas, Bicol or Calabarzon (Region 2)
Predicted wind speed of 118 km/h in Caraga or Davao regions (Region 3)
trigger_statement_3.source_authority: Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA)
trigger_statement_3.geographic_scope: Regions 1, 2, and 3 of the Philippines as specified
trigger_statement_3.preliminary_actions: Supports alignment with official forecasts and early warnings; facilitates institutionalization of anticipatory action; allows response to rapid cyclone intensification.

trigger_mechanism.description: The trigger system works in a sequenced dual-trigger manner with two activation stages: first, a seasonal scale trigger to increase preparation at the national society level based on above-normal seasonal rainfall forecasts; second, a short-scale trigger to implement early actions based on extreme rainfall forecasts with a 7-day lead time. The short-scale trigger requires both a high EFI index forecast and an extreme rain forecast from the national meteorological agency. There is no mention of a stop or deactivation mechanism.

trigger_statement_1.statement: On a seasonal scale (information available in May with a two-month lead-time): above-normal seasonal rainfall forecasts, issued by the National Meteorological Agency (ANAM). This forecast will be transmitted by the Weather Department by correspondence to the DM department of the CRT.
thresholds: Above-normal seasonal rainfall forecast
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: National Meteorological Agency of Chad (ANAM)
trigger_statement_1.lead_time: Two months ahead (information available in May)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Chad, specifically high-risk provinces: Moyen Chari, Mandoul, Logone Oriental, Tandjilé, Mayo Kebbi West, Salamat
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Increase preparation of the national society on the scale of the wet season

trigger_statement_2.statement: Short-scale (7 days lead-time): Weekly EFI index forecasts from the ECMWF model > 0.8 AND ANAM extreme rain forecast.
thresholds: Weekly Extreme Forecast Index (EFI) from ECMWF model greater than 0.8
Extreme rain forecast from National Meteorological Agency of Chad (ANAM)
trigger_statement_2.source_authority: European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF) and National Meteorological Agency of Chad (ANAM)
trigger_statement_2.geographic_scope: Chad, specifically high-risk provinces: Moyen Chari, Mandoul, Logone Oriental, Tandjilé, Mayo Kebbi West, Salamat
trigger_statement_2.preliminary_actions: Implementation of early actions including readiness and prepositioning activities

trigger_mechanism.description: The drought trigger mechanism is based on a dual-trigger system using two datasets: the merged Standard Precipitation Index (SPI-12) forecast produced by ICPAC to capture hazard forecasts, and the Food Insecurity projection produced by FEWSNET to capture dynamic vulnerability. Anticipatory actions are triggered when both conditions are met in the same district. The system includes a stop mechanism activated when subsequent data indicate an improvement in the food security situation.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: The stop mechanism is activated by the Somali Red Crescent Society (SRCS) when subsequent monthly SPI-12 data and FEWSNET projections indicate an improvement in the projected food security situation. The FbF/EAP Manager communicates with Disaster Risk Management Directors who assess and confirm the change, then notify branches and volunteers to inform communities.

trigger_statement_1.statement: When ICPAC issues an SPI-12 forecast of less than -1 for a district AND the FEWSNET food insecurity projection reaches at least 0.7 in its derived population-weighted index in the same district, then Anticipatory Actions will be triggered in the district.
thresholds: SPI-12 forecast less than -1 for a district
FEWSNET food insecurity projection at least 0.7 in derived population-weighted index in the same district
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: ICPAC (SPI-12 forecast), FEWSNET (Food Insecurity projection)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: District level in Somalia
trigger_statement_1.condition_dependency: Both conditions (SPI-12 < -1 and FEWSNET projection ≥ 0.7) must be met simultaneously in the same district to trigger anticipatory actions.
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Upon trigger thresholds being reached, the Technical Data Officer notifies the EAP/FbF Manager who verifies and relays the notification to Disaster Risk Management Directors for activation. Readiness activities include yearly refresher trainings for volunteers on Cash, WASH, and Early Warning Communication to ensure readiness for implementation.

trigger_mechanism.description: The Early Action Protocol (EAP) for cold waves in Kyrgyzstan is activated based on weather forecasts issued by Kyrgyzhydromet. The trigger is a forecast of a cold wave with a lead time of four days, confirmed by a 72-hour forecast with at least 75% probability. Activation is manual, with alerts disseminated by Kyrgyzhydromet to relevant partners including the Red Crescent Society of Kyrgyzstan (RCSK). The RCSK president activates the EAP upon receiving the alert. A stop mechanism exists to halt early actions if the probability of the cold wave occurrence falls below 75% at 72 hours before the event.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: If the probability of the occurrence of a cold wave with a lead time of 72 hours is less than 75%, the Stop Mechanism is activated by the RCSK Head of the Disaster Management department upon receiving the corresponding message from Kyrgyzhydromet. This stops the implementation of early actions including distribution, registration/verification of beneficiaries, and publication of press releases. If later forecasts confirm the cold wave, early actions are resumed.

trigger_statement_1.statement: The EAP presented in this plan targets a cold wave and is triggered by a forecast provided by Kyrgyzhydromet with a lead time of four days. Having the local and regional models with high resolution, the forecast for 72 hours will be used as a confirmation of cold wave occurrence. If the probability of the occurrence of a cold wave with a lead time of 72 hours is less than 75 per cent, the Stop Mechanism will be activated by the RCSK Head of the DM department upon receiving the corresponding message from Kyrgyzhydromet.
thresholds: Forecast of cold wave with a lead time of 4 days
72-hour forecast confirmation with at least 75% probability of cold wave occurrence
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Kyrgyzhydromet (Hydrometeorological Service under the Ministry of Emergency Situations of the Kyrgyz Republic)
trigger_statement_1.lead_time: 4 days with confirmation at 72 hours before the event
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Kyrgyzstan, specifically high-risk provinces including Chuy, Naryn, Osh, Talas, Jalal-Abad, Batken, and Issyk-Kul
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Early actions can be implemented in the window between the forecast and the event. The RCSK prepares intervention maps, identifies vulnerable families, and mobilizes staff and volunteers. If the stop mechanism is activated, early actions such as distribution, beneficiary registration, and press releases are halted.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP uses a dual-stage trigger system based on ECMWF rainfall forecasts. A readiness trigger activates preparedness actions 7 days ahead when forecasted 24-hour rainfall totals reach or exceed 20mm across western Yemen including Hajjah Governorate. An activation trigger initiates early actions 3 days ahead when the same rainfall threshold is forecasted within 72 hours over northwestern Yemen including Hajjah. The triggers are conditional: activation follows readiness. There is no mention of a stop or deactivation mechanism.

trigger_statement_1.statement: Readiness Trigger: The readiness trigger will be met when the median ensemble member of the ECMWF forecast indicates that 24-hour rainfall totals will be 20mm or above, looking at a time window of 7 days ahead across western Yemen (including Hajjah Governorate). Activation Trigger: The activation trigger will be met when the median ensemble member of the ECMWF forecast indicates that 24-hour rainfall totals will be 20 mm or above, looking at a time window within 3 days (72 hours) over the northwestern part of the country (including Hajjah Governorate).
thresholds: 24-hour rainfall totals of 20mm or above forecasted 7 days ahead across western Yemen including Hajjah Governorate
24-hour rainfall totals of 20mm or above forecasted within 3 days (72 hours) over northwestern Yemen including Hajjah Governorate
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: ECMWF
trigger_statement_1.lead_time: 7 days for readiness trigger; 3 days (72 hours) for activation trigger
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Western Yemen including Hajjah Governorate for readiness; Northwestern Yemen including Hajjah Governorate for activation
trigger_statement_1.condition_dependency: Activation trigger is conditional on the readiness trigger being met first
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Upon readiness trigger (7 days lead time): activate branch disaster response team; begin dissemination of early warning messages and advisories; recheck and verify beneficiary household lists; notify financial service providers to prepare cash distribution logistics. Upon activation trigger (3 days lead time): distribute emergency shelter/repair kits; deliver sandbags and flood mitigation supplies; conduct drainage cleaning; distribute cash assistance; equip community committees with first aid kits and stretchers; disseminate early warning messages and awareness campaigns.

trigger_mechanism.description: The early action protocol uses a dual-trigger system where early actions are activated based on weather forecasts from two sources: ICPAC and IGEBU. The triggers can activate either when ICPAC forecasts indicate a high probability of extreme rainfall seven days ahead, or when both ICPAC and IGEBU forecasts indicate imminent heavy rainfall within three days. The triggers are not conditional on each other but can activate independently based on the stated criteria. There is no mention of a stop or deactivation mechanism.

trigger_statement_1.statement:
The early actions of this early action protocol will be triggered when:  
1. ICPAC forecasts indicate that the 99th percentile of daily precipitation totals will be exceeded with a probability of 60% or more seven days before impact.  
OR 
2. When, concomitantly, IGEBU forecasts indicate that the historical threshold of 25 mm in 24 hours will be exceeded and ICPAC forecasts indicate that the 99th percentile of daily precipitation totals will be exceeded with a probability of 60% or more within the next three days.
thresholds: ICPAC forecasts indicate that the 99th percentile of daily precipitation totals will be exceeded with a probability of 60% or more seven days before impact
IGEBU forecasts indicate that the historical threshold of 25 mm in 24 hours will be exceeded
ICPAC forecasts indicate that the 99th percentile of daily precipitation totals will be exceeded with a probability of 60% or more within the next three days
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: ICPAC (IGAD Climate Prediction and Application Centre), IGEBU (Burundi Geographic Institute)
trigger_statement_1.lead_time: 7 days for ICPAC forecast in threshold 1; 3 days for combined ICPAC and IGEBU forecast in threshold 2
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Nationwide Burundi, with focus on communes of Ntahangwa, Mukaza, Muha, Muhuta, Rumonge and Bukemba
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Monitoring of forecasts by trained Burundi Red Cross staff supported by IGEBU and Red Cross Red Crescent Climate Centre; early warning bulletins to notify when thresholds are reached; readiness activities include cash training for volunteers and public awareness raising; prioritized early actions include household identification and cash distribution.

trigger_mechanism.description: The Early Action Protocol (EAP) uses a multi-stage trigger mechanism based on flood forecasts and river water levels from authoritative sources. A readiness trigger is activated 3 to 5 days ahead based on probabilistic flood flow forecasts and rainfall predictions. This is followed by an activation trigger with a 48-hour lead time based on predicted river water levels exceeding danger thresholds. The triggers are monitored using flood bulletins, numerical weather predictions, and flood outlooks. There is a stop mechanism for evacuation actions, which only proceed once real-time river levels surpass danger levels and show a rising trend.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: Evacuation of vulnerable populations and livestock will only be implemented once the rivers surpass the danger level based on real-time river status from DHM and are in a rising trend at respective gauging stations.

trigger_statement_1.statement: The Department of Hydrology and Meteorology (DHM) of Nepal issues a three-day flood and weather bulletin on a daily basis during the monsoon season. The flood bulletin includes the river level forecast information indicating the likely trend of river levels and a prediction on whether the river will flow above or below the danger level at different river gauge stations. This also includes the river level forecast information of Karnali, Babai and West Rapti at Chisapani, Chepang and Kusum stations respectively. Depending on the severity of flood flows and associated risk level, respective rivers and their downstream districts are also highlighted with different colors – yellow, amber and red. These flood bulletins are produced based on the forecast outcomes from the DHM’s flood forecasting models (HEC HMS & Mike 11). Also, there is an operational Regional Flood Outlook from ICIMOD which covers Karnali and West Rapti rivers. The weather bulletin however provides information on the rainfall forecast for the next three days. Also, in case of any significant weather phenomenon, special weather advisories or flood advisories are also issued by DHM a few days in advance. For the real-time monitoring of triggers, the existing IBF in the BIPAD system shall be utilized, which will fetch the GLOFAS data and put a readiness alert in the system. Regarding the DHM Forecast bulletin and other relevant rainfall forecast sources, this will be manually monitored by the NRCS (with support from Climate Centre and DHM) and accordingly, the activation trigger will be confirmed.”) Readiness Trigger (3-5 days lead time) The readiness trigger for Karnali, Babai and West Rapti will be reached when Global Flood Awareness System (GLOFAS) predicts more than 2-year return period flow in next 3 to 5 days with a probability of 50% or more at Chisapani, Chepang and Kusum station respectively. Alternatively, the readiness trigger for Babai and West Rapti will also be confirmed when the numerical weather prediction (NWP) from DHM/RIMES or any special weather advisories/bulletin from DHM predicts extreme and widespread rainfall for next three days across those basin areas and districts provided that these rivers are already flowing at stage level less than 2m from existing danger level. Activation Trigger (48h lead time): River Station Name Existing Danger Threshold River Name Level (metre) Level (metre) Karnali Chisapani 10.8 11.8 West Rapti Kusum 7.8 7.8 Babai Chepang 6.8 6.8 The activation trigger for Karnali will be reached when the DHM flood forecast bulletin or regional flood outlook from ICIMOD or any special flood advisories from DHM predict the water level of Karnali in Chisapani to rise 1 metre above the existing danger level in the next 48 hours.
thresholds: GLOFAS predicts more than 2-year return period flow in next 3 to 5 days with a probability of 50% or more at Chisapani, Chepang and Kusum stations

Numerical weather prediction (NWP) or special weather advisories predict extreme and widespread rainfall for next three days across Babai and West Rapti basin areas and districts, provided rivers are flowing at stage level less than 2m below existing danger level
Activation trigger for Karnali: predicted water level at Chisapani station to rise 1 metre above existing danger level (10.8m) within next 48 hours
Activation trigger for West Rapti: predicted water level at Kusum station to reach existing danger level (7.8m) within next 48 hours
Activation trigger for Babai: predicted water level at Chepang station to reach existing danger level (6.8m) within next 48 hours

trigger_statement_1.lead_time: 3 to 5 days for readiness trigger; 48 hours for activation trigger
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Karnali, Babai and West Rapti river basins and downstream districts in Nepal
trigger_statement_1.condition_dependency: Activation trigger depends on confirmation of readiness trigger and manual monitoring by NRCS with DHM and Climate Centre support
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Upon readiness trigger confirmation, field preparations for evacuation and relocation of prepositioned support items are completed. Following activation trigger, early warning messages are disseminated, volunteers mobilized to distribute relief items, identify vulnerable households, and manage safe shelters and livestock sheds.

trigger_statement_2.statement: The activation trigger for Babai and West Rapti River will be reached when the DHM flood forecast bulletin or regional flood outlook from ICIMOD or any special flood advisories from DHM predict water levels of Babai and West Rapti to rise to their existing danger levels in Chepang and Kusum station respectively in next 48 hours. Although, much of the operational readiness, prepositioning and preparation for proposed early action will take place well ahead following the start of monsoon, the confirmation of readiness trigger will make sure all the necessary field preparation for evacuation and relocation of prepositioned support items to local chapters/warehouses etc. are completed. Following the activation trigger with 48h lead time, the NRCS will start the process of dissemination of Early Warning Messages to the downstream communities of respective Karnali, Babai and West Rapti river. The activation trigger will also mobilise the volunteers to flood vulnerable communities of Banke, Bardiya and Kailali to distribute jerry cans, waterproof storage bags, dignity kit and hygiene kits to the most vulnerable household/population groups of at-risk areas, including supporting them in storing the movable assets and food grains in safe place. A potential list of the most vulnerable households that need to be evacuated will also be identified and validated at this stage. Also, following the activation trigger, temporary safe shelters and livestock sheds will be constructed or managed in the already identified safe areas and evacuation sites. However, the evacuation of the most vulnerable population and their livestock will only be implemented once the rivers surpass the danger level (based on the real-time river status from DHM) and are in a rising trend in respective gauging stations. This means there is a stop mechanism in place especially for the action related to the evacuation of the population.
thresholds: Predicted water levels of Babai and West Rapti rivers to rise to their existing danger levels at Chepang and Kusum stations respectively within next 48 hours
Evacuation only implemented once rivers surpass danger level and show rising trend based on real-time DHM data
trigger_statement_2.source_authority: Department of Hydrology and Meteorology (DHM) Nepal, ICIMOD
trigger_statement_2.geographic_scope: Babai and West Rapti river basins and downstream districts including Banke, Bardiya and Kailali
trigger_statement_2.condition_dependency: Evacuation actions conditional on river levels surpassing danger level and rising trend after activation trigger
trigger_statement_2.preliminary_actions: Mobilization of volunteers to distribute relief items (jerry cans, waterproof bags, dignity and hygiene kits), identification and validation of vulnerable households for evacuation, construction and management of temporary safe shelters and livestock sheds.

trigger_mechanism.description: The Early Action Protocol (EAP) for floods associated with tropical cyclones in Guatemala is activated based on two distinct triggers related to meteorological and hydrological forecasts. Trigger 1 is based on a probabilistic forecast of a tropical storm entering the cyclone emergency zone with a specified wind speed threshold and lead time. Trigger 2 is based on flood probability forecasts exceeding a threshold for a return period in high-risk flood areas. The EAP activates early actions once either trigger is met, with no indication of conditional dependencies between triggers or a stop/deactivation mechanism described.

trigger_statement_1.statement: When the National Institute of Seismology, Volcanology, Meteorology and Hydrology (INSIVUMEH) of Guatemala or the National Hurricane Center (NOAA) issues a forecast with a 60% probability that the path of a tropical storm (63 km/hr) or greater, will enter the cyclone emergency zone of the Republic of Guatemala, with a waiting time of 3 to 5 days.
thresholds: 60% probability that the path of a tropical storm (63 km/hr) or greater will enter the cyclone emergency zone of Guatemala
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: National Institute of Seismology, Volcanology, Meteorology and Hydrology (INSIVUMEH) of Guatemala and National Hurricane Center (NOAA)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Cyclone emergency zone of the Republic of Guatemala
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Early actions include registration and/or validation of families to receive support through Multipurpose Cash Transfers (MCT), distribution of MCT to selected families, dissemination of key information/messages via social networks for at least 15 days, first aid refresher courses for volunteers, purchase of first aid kits, implementation of anticipatory action workshops, simulation exercises, and updating of maps and databases for intervention areas.

trigger_statement_2.statement: When the Global Flood Awareness System (GLoFAS) forecast exceeds a 50% probability for a 3-year return period in areas of high flood risk with a 3-day lead time.
thresholds: GLoFAS forecast exceeds 50% probability for a 3-year return period flood event in high flood risk areas
trigger_statement_2.source_authority: Global Flood Awareness System (GLoFAS)
trigger_statement_2.geographic_scope: Areas of high flood risk in Guatemala
trigger_statement_2.preliminary_actions: Same as Trigger 1: includes multipurpose cash transfers, information dissemination, volunteer training, first aid kit prepositioning, anticipatory action workshops, simulation exercises, and updating intervention maps.

trigger_mechanism.description: The Early Action Protocol (EAP) for drought in Guatemala is activated based on two forecast-based triggers related to the El Niño phenomenon and seasonal precipitation forecasts. The first trigger is the issuance of an El Niño warning by INSIVUMEH with a 70% probability for the next 3 months based on the IRI forecast. The second trigger is a seasonal precipitation forecast issued by INSIVUMEH indicating a 50% probability of rainfall below the first tercile (33rd percentile) for the next 3 months. The triggers are monitored starting in June with a lead time of at least 3 months. There is a stop mechanism that allows halting actions if updated forecasts no longer meet the trigger conditions. The Guatemalan Red Cross expedites processes to implement early actions once thresholds are exceeded.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: A stop mechanism allows actions to be halted if an updated seasonal forecast no longer confirms the precipitation deficit forecast (trigger 2). There is no stop mechanism for the El Niño warning trigger (trigger 1).

trigger_statement_1.statement: Trigger 1 ⎯ When the National Institute of Seismology, Volcanology, Meteorology and Hydrology (INSIVUMEH) issues an “El Niño” warning in area 3.4, for the next 3 months with a 70% probability based on the IRI forecast as of June.
thresholds: El Niño warning issued by INSIVUMEH for area 3.4
70% probability
Forecast period: next 3 months
Forecast issued as of June

trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Area 3.4 (Pacific Ocean region relevant to Guatemala)
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Socialization of information to the Guatemalan Red Cross Management Team and IFRC; verification of available inputs; volunteers’ preparation.

trigger_statement_2.statement: Trigger 2 ⎯ When INSIVUMEH issues a bulletin or seasonal precipitation forecast from the month of June with 50% probability below the first tercile (33rd percentile) for the next 3 months.
thresholds: Seasonal precipitation forecast issued by INSIVUMEH starting in June
50% probability of precipitation below the first tercile (33rd percentile)
Forecast period: next 3 months

trigger_mechanism.description: The trigger system is a multi-stage alert mechanism based on seismic and ground deformation monitoring of the Karthala volcano. It uses three alert levels (yellow, orange, red) issued by the Observatoire Volcanologique du Karthala (OVK). Alerts are activated based on seismic crises, micro-deformations, and gas composition changes. The early action is triggered upon receipt of the orange alert bulletin four days before the expected volcanic impact, allowing prepositioning and distribution of sanitation, WASH, and dignity kits. The red alert triggers distribution of dust masks and protective glasses and supports evacuation. Sensitization starts at the yellow alert phase. The system is conditional and sequential, with orange alert activation dependent on prior yellow alert, and red alert following orange. There is no explicit stop or deactivation mechanism described.

trigger_statement_1.statement: The trigger model of Karthala volcano is presently based on seismic and ground deformations surveys (Observatoire Volcanologique du Karthala Centre National de Documentation et de la Recherche Scientifique des Comores (iavceivolcano.org). The seismic network consists now in 7 seismic stations. Each station is composed of a seismometer and various electronic devices for radio transmissions (modulator, transceiver). Telemetered radio analogical signals of seismic stations are received at the observatory where they are digitalized. A real time analogical control is supplied for 3 stations at the observatory using a lennartz drum recorder with thermic paper. Deformations monitoring is performed with: - A permanent inclinometric station composed by 4 blum-type silica inclinometers. Measurements are repeated each minute and transmitted to the observatory by radio. The orange alert is triggered when an imminent danger is detected - an anomaly higher than normal (second-level seismic crisis, second level micro-deformation of the ground, and change in the composition of gases through the accumulation of carbon dioxide) that persists for several hours a day. It includes three types of alerts that are activated after receipt of the special bulletins of level 1 for the yellow alert, level 2 for the orange alert and level 3 for the red alert, which are monitored through the periodic forecasts shared by OVK two weeks, four days and two days before the impact respectively for the yellow, the orange and the red alert. The early action trigger threshold is reached, when the CRCS receives the special orange alert bulletin (OVK-SB2) four days before the impact (fig.2). This will allow the steering committee, despite the preparedness and pre-positioning activities carried out, to proceed with the distribution of sanitation, WASH and dignity kits. If there is a need to relocate exposed populations, the CRCS will provide technical support during site identification and evacuation and will provide psychosocial support to affected populations. The red alert is reached, when the CRCS receives the special level 3 bulletin (OVK-BS3), in which case the CRCS will proceed directly to the distribution of dust masks and protective glasses to the most at-risk population before their evacuation. Sensitization activities will start from the yellow phase, while the distribution of protection kits will only start in the orange phase to protect the population and their livelihood from the dangers related to volcanic ash.
thresholds: Level 1 (yellow alert) bulletin received two weeks before impact

Level 2 (orange alert) bulletin received four days before impact, triggered by anomalies such as second-level seismic crisis, second-level micro-deformation of the ground, and changes in gas composition (carbon dioxide accumulation) persisting for several hours a day
Level 3 (red alert) bulletin received two days before impact
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Observatoire Volcanologique du Karthala (OVK), Centre National de Documentation et de la Recherche Scientifique des Comores
trigger_statement_1.lead_time: Yellow alert: 2 weeks before impact; Orange alert: 4 days before impact; Red alert: 2 days before impact
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: All areas of the big island Ngazidja, Comoros, focusing on high-risk areas including Mbadjini, Hambou, Bambao, Itsandra, Washilli and Dimani
trigger_statement_1.condition_dependency: Orange alert activation depends on prior yellow alert; red alert follows orange alert
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Sensitization activities start at yellow alert phase; distribution of sanitation, WASH, and dignity kits starts at orange alert; distribution of dust masks and protective glasses and evacuation support at red alert; technical support for site identification and psychosocial support provided if relocation is needed

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP trigger mechanism for drought in Eswatini operates as a dual-trigger system with two steps: first, a seasonal forecast issued by the Eswatini Meteorological Services indicating 'below to normal' rainfall with a lead time of 3 months, initiating readiness and low-regret actions starting in September; second, a drought monitoring trigger based on the Composite Drought Index (CDI) average observed over the October-November-December (OND) season, used in mid-January to trigger food and water-related early actions. The Disaster Management Coordinator is responsible for activation and deactivation (stop mechanism) of the EAP based on forecast information.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: The Disaster Management Coordinator manages the stop mechanism with guidance from forecast information provided by the Eswatini Meteorological Services.

trigger_statement_1.statement: The EAP will be triggered by a forecast provided by Eswatini Meteorological Services (EMS) with a lead time of 3 months (seasonal lead time) as well as the drought monitoring through the Composite Drought Index (CDI). The trigger is characterized by a 2-step triggering process: one starting in September for readiness and low-regret actions to be triggered by “below to normal” forecast issued by Eswatini Meteorological Services and the second one in mid-January based on low CDI average observed over the OND season aimed at triggering food and water-related early actions.
thresholds: Below to normal rainfall forecast issued by Eswatini Meteorological Services starting in September
Low Composite Drought Index (CDI) average observed over the October-November-December (OND) season
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Eswatini Meteorological Services
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Drought-prone areas of Eswatini, specifically the Lowveld region
trigger_statement_1.condition_dependency: The second trigger based on CDI monitoring in mid-January is conditional on the initial seasonal forecast trigger starting in September.
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Readiness and low-regret actions are initiated upon the first trigger (below to normal forecast) starting in September; food and water-related early actions are triggered upon the second trigger (low CDI average) in mid-January.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP trigger mechanism for cyclone early action in Bangladesh operates in two stages: Pre-Activation and Activation. Pre-Activation requires a Signal 4 or above warning from BMD with a lead time of 72 hours or more, combined with forecasts from at least two models (BMD, IMD, ECMWF, GFS, JTWC) predicting wind speeds of 125 km/h or greater and potential damage of 25% household assets in coastal districts. Activation requires a Signal 7 or above warning from BMD with a lead time of 30 hours or more, along with forecasts from BMD or IMD predicting wind speeds of 125 km/h or greater and potential damage of 25% household assets. The triggers are conditional in that the activation stage follows the pre-activation stage. The system does not mention a stop or deactivation mechanism explicitly.

trigger_statement_1.statement:
"When BMD issues a Signal 4 or above warning with a lead time of 72 hours or more" AND "BMD / IMD / ECMWF / GFS / JTWC (at least two models) forecasts wind speeds of 125 km/h or greater in the coastal districts of Bangladesh with a lead time of 72 hours or more AND with a potential damage of 25% household asset of the respective Unions".

or "BMD / IMD / ECMWF / GFS / JTWC (at least two models) forecasts wind speeds of 125 km/h or greater in the coastal districts of Bangladesh with a lead time of 72 hours or more AND with a potential damage of 25% household asset of the respective Unions".
thresholds: BMD issues a Signal 4 or above warning with a lead time of 72 hours or more
At least two models among BMD, IMD, ECMWF, GFS, JTWC forecast wind speeds of 125 km/h or greater in coastal districts of Bangladesh with a lead time of 72 hours or more
Potential damage of 25% household assets in the respective Unions
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Bangladesh Meteorological Department (BMD), Indian Meteorological Department (IMD), ECMWF, GFS, JTWC
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Coastal districts of Bangladesh (14 most vulnerable cyclone prone districts)
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Pre-activation stage activities include readiness actions such as orientation and training of staff and volunteers, early warning dissemination, coordination meetings, and preparation for evacuation and shelter management.

trigger_statement_2.statement:
"When BMD issues a Signal 7 or above warning with a lead time of 30 hours or more" AND "BMD / IMD forecasts wind speeds of 125 km/h or greater in the coastal districts of Bangladesh with a lead time of 30 hours or more AND with a potential damage of 25 per cent household asset of the respective Unions".

or "BMD / IMD forecasts wind speeds of 125 km/h or greater in the coastal districts of Bangladesh with a lead time of 30 hours or more AND with a potential damage of 25 per cent household asset of the respective Unions".
thresholds: BMD issues a Signal 7 or above warning with a lead time of 30 hours or more
BMD or IMD forecast wind speeds of 125 km/h or greater in coastal districts of Bangladesh with a lead time of 30 hours or more
Potential damage of 25% household assets in the respective Unions
trigger_statement_2.source_authority: Bangladesh Meteorological Department (BMD), Indian Meteorological Department (IMD)
trigger_statement_2.geographic_scope: Coastal districts of Bangladesh (14 most vulnerable cyclone prone districts)
trigger_statement_2.condition_dependency: Activation stage is conditional on the pre-activation stage being met first
trigger_statement_2.preliminary_actions: Activation stage triggers implementation of early actions including dissemination of early warning messages, evacuation support for people and livestock, distribution of food, water, ORS, hygiene items at cyclone shelters, and cyclone shelter management support.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP activation is based on a single trigger mechanism relying on cyclone forecasts from the National Meteorological Institute (INAM). INAM issues cyclone alerts based on forecasted wind speeds at landfall. The Technical Committee for Disaster Management (CTGC) reviews these alerts and decides on official disaster alerts. The EAP can only be activated by the Cruz Vermelha de Mozambique (CVM) following the official announcement by CTGC. The trigger is primarily a forecast of a category 3 cyclone with wind speeds of 120 km/h or more at landfall, forecasted at least 72 hours in advance. There is a conditional possibility to activate below this threshold (at 100 km/h) based on expert consensus considering increased vulnerability or compounding risks. A stop mechanism exists to halt activation if the cyclone changes course before community notification or distribution begins, but not after mobilization to avoid community friction.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: If the cyclone changes track dramatically before communities have been notified or distributions have begun, the distribution will be stopped and materials returned to the warehouse. However, if communities have already been mobilized or notified, the stop mechanism will not take effect to avoid causing friction between local authorities, CVM, and beneficiaries.

trigger_statement_1.statement:
The threshold or trigger for activation of this EAP will be a category 3 cyclone with an anticipated speed of 120 km/h or more at landfall, as indicated by INAM in their 72-hour forecast. This corresponds to an event with a return period of 5 years.

In exceptional cases, the EAP may be activated below the trigger threshold of 120 km/h it means 100km/h based on expert consensus, if levels of vulnerability have significantly increased at the time of activation due to compounding risks which emerged after the finalization of the EAP (e.g. onset of a pandemic) or because the exposed area has recently been impacted by another natural extreme event and find itself in the process of recovery and reconstruction. A consensus must be reached between CVM and IFRC, based on consultations of Government partners and technical experts from the NHMS at national and regional level, as well as the Red Cross and Red Crescent Climate Centre (RCCC).
thresholds: Category 3 cyclone with anticipated wind speed of 120 km/h or more at landfall
Exceptional activation possible at 100 km/h wind speed based on expert consensus due to increased vulnerability or compounding risks
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: National Meteorological Institute (INAM), Technical Committee for Disaster Management (CTGC), Cruz Vermelha de Mozambique (CVM), IFRC, Red Cross and Red Crescent Climate Centre (RCCC)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Coastal districts in northern and central Mozambique, maximum of three districts simultaneously
trigger_statement_1.condition_dependency: Activation below 120 km/h threshold requires expert consensus between CVM and IFRC, considering government and technical expert consultations, and is conditional on increased vulnerability or compounding risks such as pandemics or recent natural disasters.
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Upon trigger activation, CVM volunteers are activated, information dissemination on the cyclone is conducted, and early actions such as reinforcement of houses and schools, distribution of shelter and WASH kits, and community engagement activities are initiated.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP trigger mechanism is a single-trigger system based on meteorological forecasts. The National Meteorological Institute (INAM) issues cyclone alerts, and the EAP is activated when a category 3 cyclone with forecasted wind speeds of 120 km/h or more at landfall is predicted at least 72 hours in advance. Activation requires consensus and official announcement by the Technical Committee for Disaster Management (CTGC). There is a stop mechanism that can deactivate the EAP if the cyclone changes course before community notification or distribution begins.

However, if communities have been mobilized, the stop mechanism will not take effect to avoid friction.
