This corresponds to an event with a return period of 5 years. In exceptional cases, the EAP may be activated below the trigger threshold of 120 km/h it means 100km/h based on expert consensus, if levels of vulnerability have significantly increased at the time of activation due to compounding risks which emerged after the finalization of the EAP (e.g. onset of a pandemic) or because the exposed area has recently been impacted by another natural extreme event and find itself in the process of recovery and reconstruction. A consensus must be reached between CVM and IFRC, based on consultations of Government partners and technical experts from the NHMS at national and regional level, as well as the Red Cross and Red Crescent Climate Centre (RCCC).
thresholds: Category 3 cyclone with anticipated wind speed of 120 km/h or more at landfall
Exceptional activation possible at 100 km/h wind speed based on expert consensus due to increased vulnerability or compounding risks
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: National Meteorological Institute (INAM), Technical Committee for Disaster Management (CTGC), Cruz Vermelha de Mozambique (CVM), IFRC, Red Cross and Red Crescent Climate Centre (RCCC)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Coastal districts in northern and central Mozambique, maximum of three districts simultaneously
trigger_statement_1.condition_dependency: Activation requires official disaster alert announcement by the Technical Committee for Disaster Management (CTGC) after INAM issues the forecast; exceptional activation below threshold requires consensus between CVM and IFRC with government and expert consultation.
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Based on the forecast, CVM activates volunteers, disseminates information, selects focus districts and communities, and prepares for distribution of materials and early actions.

trigger_mechanism.description: The Early Action Protocol (EAP) for floods in Mozambique uses a dual-trigger system based on hydrological forecasts. The primary trigger is the water level at upstream river basin reference stations reaching the discharge level corresponding to a five-year return period, providing approximately 3 days lead time for early action. An alternative trigger uses GloFAS hydrological forecasts for the Buzi and Licungo rivers, offering up to 7 days lead time. The triggers are not conditional on each other but serve as complementary mechanisms to allow earlier activation where possible. A stop mechanism exists to halt actions if flood characteristics change significantly before community notification or distribution begins.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: If the flood changes dramatically such that selected communities are unlikely to be impacted, and this occurs before communities have been notified or distributions have started, activities and distributions will be stopped and materials returned to the warehouse. The stop mechanism does not apply once communities have been mobilized to avoid friction.

trigger_statement_1.statement: The actions proposed will be activated on the basis of hydro-meteorological warnings indicating that the trigger level (water level correspondent to discharge of five-year return period at the river basin reference station) will be reached within 72 hours (3 days), which is the lead time within which the CVM can act in advance before a flood event reaches the districts and communities potentially at risk.
thresholds: Water level corresponding to discharge of five-year return period at the river basin reference station
Trigger level reached within 72 hours (3 days)
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: National Institute of Meteorology (INAM), National Directorate of Water Resources Management (DNGRH), REPRESA project through GloFAS
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Mozambique, specifically four hydrographic basins: Limpopo, Buzi, Zambezi, and Licungo; with focus on 12 at-risk districts downstream in Gaza, Sofala, and Zambezia provinces
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Early actions based on preparation time window of 3 days before flood impact; readiness and prepositioning activities funded and implemented

trigger_statement_2.statement: This EAP will also incorporate GloFAS as an alternative trigger for the Buzi and Licungo rivers, where the model demonstrates sufficient capabilities, providing a lead time of approximately 7 days for Buzi and Licungo. Despite the Limpopo River presenting indications lower than the previous ones, they are still sufficient for use, given its lead time of 3 to 7 days, which is longer compared to the current practice of 3 days.
thresholds: GloFAS forecast indicating flood risk with approximately 7 days lead time for Buzi and Licungo rivers
GloFAS forecast indicating flood risk with 3 to 7 days lead time for Limpopo river
trigger_statement_2.source_authority: REPRESA project through GloFAS
trigger_statement_2.geographic_scope: Buzi and Licungo river basins primarily, also Limpopo river basin
trigger_statement_2.preliminary_actions: Allows CVM to act earlier than the primary trigger, providing a crucial safety margin for early actions

trigger_mechanism.description: The Early Action Protocol (EAP) for population movement associated with migration of people in transit is activated based on a consensus-based forecast and a single trigger mechanism. The trigger is decided by the Steering Committee of the Migration Roundtable, which analyzes data on population flows and the national context to determine if the scenario becomes an extreme event with a high probability of flows of people in transit exceeding regular monthly thresholds. Activation implies insufficient operational and financial capacity to deal with the threat in the coming weeks or months. The lead time for activation is between 30 to 90 days. The trigger is based on multiple data sources and technical and steering committees' analysis. There is no mention of a stop or deactivation mechanism.

trigger_statement_1.statement: The activation statement defines that the trigger will be reached when two months of positive flow trend and a projection of more than 23,000 people (5% of the highest monthly flow) crossing the border for the following month, as well as a 40% decrease of the response capacity, will activate early actions prioritizing the most vulnerable migrants.
thresholds: Two months of positive flow trend
Projection of more than 23,000 people (5% of the highest monthly flow) crossing the border for the following month
40% decrease of the response capacity
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Steering Committee of the Migration Roundtable, based on data from National Migration Institute of Honduras (INM), National Migration Service of Panama, IFRC GO Platform, International Organization for Migration (IOM)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: National scope within Honduras, considering migratory routes and points of greatest agglomeration along the route and humanitarian service points where Honduran Red Cross has presence
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Early actions prioritizing the most vulnerable migrants are implemented once the trigger is met. Selection of intervention sites is based on points of greatest agglomeration and humanitarian service points.

trigger_statement_2.statement: Single trigger - The Steering Committee of the Migration Roundtable decides that the EAP is activated based on the data on population flows and the national context, and decides that the scenario becomes an extreme event with a high probability of flows of people in transit, exceeding the "regular" monthly thresholds of population flows with an initial execution time between 30 to 90 days, which implies insufficient operational and financial capacity to deal with the threat in the coming weeks or months.
thresholds: High probability of flows of people in transit exceeding regular monthly thresholds
Initial execution time between 30 to 90 days
Insufficient operational and financial capacity to deal with the threat in coming weeks or months
trigger_statement_2.source_authority: Steering Committee of the Migration Roundtable
trigger_statement_2.geographic_scope: National Honduras
trigger_statement_2.preliminary_actions: Activation leads to implementation of early actions based on forecast information and risk analysis.

trigger_mechanism.description: The Early Action Protocol (EAP) activation for floods associated with tropical storms in Honduras requires meeting two criteria simultaneously: a forecast of a tropical storm with a minimum probability threshold and a flood forecast exceeding a probability threshold in high flood hazard areas. Both triggers must be met for activation, with lead times of 3 to 5 days for the tropical storm forecast and 3 days for the flood forecast. The system is a dual-trigger mechanism with no mention of a stop or deactivation mechanism.

trigger_statement_1.statement: Trigger 1 ⎯ CENAOS or NOAA issues a forecast with a 60% probability of a tropical storm (34 knots) or greater reaching the warning area with a lead time of between 3 to 5 days.
thresholds: 60% probability of a tropical storm (34 knots) or greater reaching the warning area
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: CENAOS or NOAA (National Hurricane Center)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Warning area in Honduras
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Readiness and preparation activities can be initiated based on this forecast, including coordination among stakeholders and prepositioning of resources, but full activation requires meeting Trigger 2 as well.

trigger_statement_2.statement: Trigger 2 ⎯ When the GEOGLOWS/GloFAS forecast exceeds 50% probability for a 10-year return period in high flood hazard areas with a 3-day lead time.
thresholds: Exceeds 50% probability for a 10-year return period flood event in high flood hazard areas
trigger_statement_2.source_authority: GEOGLOWS/GloFAS
trigger_statement_2.geographic_scope: High flood hazard areas in Honduras
trigger_statement_2.preliminary_actions: Flood-specific early actions such as community alerts and resource mobilization can be prepared, but full activation requires meeting Trigger 1 as well.

trigger_mechanism.description: The Early Action Protocol (EAP) for floods caused by tropical cyclones in Costa Rica uses a dual-trigger system based on meteorological forecasts from the National Meteorological Institute (IMN). Trigger 1 is based on a forecast of a tropical storm entering a specified risk zone with a minimum probability threshold and lead time. Trigger 2 is based on forecasts of extreme rainfall accumulation exceeding specific thresholds over a 5-day horizon, with provisions for direct activation and a stop mechanism if rainfall forecasts decrease. Trigger 2 can activate the EAP independently of Trigger 1 to mitigate missed events. The system includes a stop mechanism that deactivates early actions if updated forecasts indicate rainfall below thresholds after activation.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: If after activation of Trigger 2, an updated forecast on day 2 indicates that extreme rainfall exceeding 300 mm cumulative rainfall over a 3-day horizon is no longer expected, the stop mechanism is activated to halt early actions.

trigger_statement_1.statement: Information from the National Meteorological Institute (IMN), on the forecast of a tropical storm with a trajectory entering at least Zone 3 indicated in the IMN Emergency Protocol, with a 60% probability and a lead time of 5 days.
thresholds: Forecast of a tropical storm entering at least Zone 3 as per IMN Emergency Protocol
60% probability of occurrence
Lead time of 5 days
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: National Meteorological Institute (IMN)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: At least Zone 3 as indicated in the IMN Emergency Protocol, Costa Rica
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Monitoring of IMN updates; technical meetings to analyze information; GIS analysis of areas of influence; preparation of intervention maps; coordination with National Directorate of Risk Management and Emergency Response (DINAGER); coordination with local committees and authorities; preparation of financial, human, and logistical resources; establishment of communication channels with communities.

trigger_statement_2.statement: Occurs when the IMN issues a forecast of extreme rainfall with a high probability of exceeding 400 mm of accumulated precipitation for a 5-day horizon, currently the EAP is activated. If an update of the forecast is given on day 2 after trigger 2 has been activated, indicating that if extreme rainfall exceeding 300 mm cumulative rainfall is forecast for a 3-day horizon, the established early actions would continue. Otherwise, the stop mechanism is activated. Trigger 2 may be declared directly when cumulative rainfall of between 300 and 400 mm is forecast, in association with the formation of a tropical depression in danger zone "1 or 2". Regardless of whether the zone trigger has been met as stated in Trigger 1, Trigger 2 can be declared directly and activate this EAP to mitigate the risk of missed events, when cumulative rainfall of between 300 and 400 mm is forecast, in association with the formation of a tropical depression in the danger zone "1 or 2".
thresholds: Forecast of extreme rainfall with high probability of exceeding 400 mm accumulated precipitation over 5 days
If updated forecast on day 2 after activation indicates rainfall exceeding 300 mm over 3 days, early actions continue
Trigger 2 may be declared directly when cumulative rainfall between 300 and 400 mm is forecast
Association with formation of tropical depression in danger zone 1 or 2
trigger_statement_2.source_authority: National Meteorological Institute (IMN)
trigger_statement_2.lead_time: 5 days (initial forecast), with updates at day 2 after activation
trigger_statement_2.geographic_scope: Danger zones 1 or 2 in Costa Rica
trigger_statement_2.condition_dependency: Trigger 2 can activate independently of Trigger 1
trigger_statement_2.preliminary_actions: Activation of early actions including multi-purpose cash distribution, coordination with local authorities and communities, preparation of resources; continuation or cessation of actions based on updated forecasts.

trigger_mechanism.description: The Early Action Protocol (EAP) for volcanic ash fall in Ecuador uses a multi-stage dual-trigger system based on volcanic activity reports and ash fall modeling. Trigger 1 activates awareness actions upon significant changes in volcano internal activity (Special Report A). Trigger 2 activates funding requests and full EAP activation upon increased volcanic activity parameters (Special Report B) and/or an eruptive event with ash fall exceeding 2 mm as modeled by ASH3D (Special Report C). The triggers are conditional: Trigger 2 depends on the occurrence of Trigger 1. A stop mechanism exists via Special Report B indicating decreased or stabilized volcanic activity, which deactivates interventions.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: The stop mechanism is defined by the issuance of Special Report B, which updates the internal activity of the volcano. When this report indicates that the internal activity (seismicity, degassing, deformation) has decreased and stabilized, interventions in affected communities are lifted. Special Report B can be issued anytime after Reports A or C.

trigger_statement_1.statement: Trigger 1: The EAP will activate actions of the Ecuadorian Red Cross in terms of awareness in high-risk areas with a spatial report A, indicating significant changes in the internal activity of a volcano. This type of report is issued when a significant change, increase in this case, in the internal activity of the volcano (seismicity, gas, deformation, etc.) is observed.
thresholds: Significant increase in internal volcanic activity parameters such as seismicity, gas emissions, deformation
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: IGEPN (Geophysical Institute of the National Polytechnic School)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: High-risk areas in Ecuador, specifically provinces Chimborazo and Bolívar mentioned
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Sensitization and training of volunteers on volcanic ash formation, evolution, monitoring, dispersion, deposit characteristics, and protective measures before, during, and after ash fall; deployment of trained volunteers to execute awareness plans; delivery of dissemination and awareness-raising materials; registration of potentially affected people; prepositioning of health and livelihood protection kits and water source protection implements in strategic warehouses.

trigger_statement_2.statement: Trigger 2: The EAP will activate the request for funds with a special report B (Increase of parameters of internal activity of the volcano) and/or with a spatial report C, which indicates an eruptive event with an explosive index (VEI 3) with possible impact on the communities. The ASH3D Ash Fall and Dispersion Model of the IGEPN should indicate at least that the 2 mm ash fall in the communities is exceeded.
thresholds: Increase in parameters of internal volcanic activity (Special Report B)
Eruptive event with explosive index VEI 3 and ash fall exceeding 2 mm as per ASH3D model (Special Report C)
trigger_statement_2.source_authority: IGEPN (Geophysical Institute of the National Polytechnic School), ASH3D Ash Fall and Dispersion Model
trigger_statement_2.geographic_scope: Communities potentially impacted by volcanic ash fall, including provinces Chimborazo and Bolívar
trigger_statement_2.condition_dependency: Conditional on prior activation of Trigger 1 (Special Report A) indicating significant changes in volcanic activity
trigger_statement_2.preliminary_actions: Keep National Society on alert administratively and operationally; prepare volunteers and technical equipment for immediate deployment; distribution of volcanic ash fall protection kits (N95 masks, eye protection glasses); awareness-raising on use of protective materials and self-protection measures; distribution of livelihood protection kits (plastic tarpaulin and toolkits for temporary shelters); multisectoral distribution of Cash and Voucher Assistance (CVA) to affected families; protection of water sources with distribution of jerrycans and plastic tarps; development of awareness actions on safe water consumption.

trigger_mechanism.description: The Early Action Protocol (sEAP) for extreme heat in Greece is triggered by a single trigger mechanism based on the issuance of a Heat Alert by the National Observatory of Athens (NOA). The trigger activates when NOA issues a Category 3 Heat Alert predicting an excess mortality rate of 45% or higher, with a lead time of five days to implement early actions. Lower categories (0-2) do not trigger early actions but prompt awareness activities. The system is a single-trigger mechanism with no explicit stop or deactivation mechanism described.

trigger_statement_1.statement: The sEAP trigger will be reached when NOA issues a Heat Alert category 3, with a predicted excess mortality rate of 45% or higher, within a five-day lead time to implement the early action activities.
thresholds: Category 1 – 1% to 12.49% excess mortality
Category 2 – 12.5% to 29.9% excess mortality
Category 3 – 30% or higher excess mortality (ranging upwards as high as 45% to 65% excess daily mortality)
Trigger threshold: Category 3 with predicted excess mortality of 45% or higher
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: National Observatory of Athens (NOA) using the Arsht-Rockefeller and Atlantic Council Extreme Temperature Categorization system
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Cities of Athens, Patras, and Thessaloniki, Greece
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Heat Alerts from categories 0 to 2 do not trigger early actions but prompt the Hellenic Red Cross Society (HRCS) to commence usual heat activities within existing capacity to raise awareness and prevent suffering and loss of life.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP trigger mechanism for drought in Ethiopia uses a dual-trigger system with two main activation points: the first trigger is based on seasonal forecast indicators one month before the season starts, and the second trigger is based on crop yield reduction predictions one month after the season starts. The system includes a stop mechanism if the moisture or Water Requirement Satisfaction Index (WRSI) does not reach critical levels.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: If the moisture or Water Requirement Satisfaction Index (WRSI) does not show critical levels (i.e., does not pass the threshold), a stop mechanism is initiated to halt early action implementation.

trigger_statement_1.statement: The ERCS will activate the EAP with the first trigger (one month ahead of a season) when the seasonal forecast (provided by the ECMWF/ICPAC and EMI) indicated that more than 50% of the geographical area of a zone is predicted to be drier than normal conditions SPI<-1, and at least 40% probability of below normal for JJA season and 45% probability of below normal OND and MAM seasons with a 1-month lead time. The second activation will be triggered (one month after the start of the season) when the crop yield reduction is predicted to be more than 50% based on LEAP index
thresholds: More than 50% of the geographical area of a zone predicted to be drier than normal conditions (SPI < -1)
At least 40% probability of below normal rainfall for JJA season
At least 45% probability of below normal rainfall for OND and MAM seasons
Crop yield reduction predicted to be more than 50% based on LEAP index
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: ECMWF, ICPAC, EMI, LEAP model
trigger_statement_1.lead_time: 1 month in advance of the season for first trigger; 1 month after the start of the season for second trigger
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Zones in Ethiopia where more than 50% of the geographical area is predicted drier than normal; drought-prone areas including Belg receiving (East and West Harerge), Northern pastorals (Afar Zone 1 and Zone 3, Northern Shewa, North and South Wollo, South Gonder, Southern Tigray), and Southern pastoral livelihood zones (seven zones in Somali, Borena and Guji, Erer, and East Bale zones)
trigger_statement_1.condition_dependency: The second trigger (crop yield reduction) is conditional on the first trigger (seasonal forecast indicating drought conditions) being met.
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Upon first trigger, community-owned activities and early warning dissemination are initiated; automated alerts sent to TWG members; urgent TWG meeting called by Ethiopian Disaster Risk Management Commission (EDRMC) to facilitate early actions; early action command team may be organized.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP uses a two-stage trigger mechanism consisting of a pre-activation and an activation trigger based on weather forecasts. Pre-activation requires forecasted temperature and heat index thresholds to be met 5-7 days in advance, while activation uses similar thresholds but with a shorter lead time of 2-3 days and different forecast sources. The trigger committee monitors forecasts and can stop activation if forecasts no longer meet criteria. Once activated, early actions proceed regardless of subsequent forecast changes.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: After the pre-activation trigger (5-7 days lead time), the forecast is closely observed until the activation lead time. A stop mechanism is set at 4, 3, and 2 days before the potential heatwave. If the forecast 2-3 days prior indicates the heatwave will not meet activation thresholds, the trigger committee will stop the activation and early actions implementation. However, if early actions have started, they will continue.

trigger_statement_1.statement: Pre-activation: to activate the pre-activation trigger, the forecast (from ECMWF and/or GFS) needs to meet two thresholds – a temperature of 38°C or more for 2 two consecutive days, and a heat index of 38 or more for two consecutive days. The expected lead time is 5–7 days. Activation: the activation trigger has a same threshold as pre-activation. However, the source of the forecast is BMD and either ECMWF or GFS; and the expected lead time is 2-3 days.
thresholds: Temperature of 38°C or more for two consecutive days
Heat index of 38 or more for two consecutive days
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: ECMWF and/or GFS for pre-activation; Bangladesh Meteorological Department (BMD) and either ECMWF or GFS for activation
trigger_statement_1.lead_time: 5-7 days for pre-activation; 2-3 days for activation
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Dhaka City area
trigger_statement_1.condition_dependency: Activation trigger depends on pre-activation trigger being met first
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Upon pre-activation, early targeting and preparation begin including mapping of most impacted Thanas and ranking by impact level. Early actions are planned and readiness activities are conducted.

trigger_mechanism.description: The Early Action Protocol (EAP) for heatwave in Kyrgyzstan is triggered based on a weather forecast by Kyrgyzhydromet. The trigger activates when the seven-day forecast indicates that temperature will exceed the 85th percentile for three or more consecutive days during June to August, with a lead time of four days. The trigger is monitored with official weather bulletins with a tolerance of ±2 degrees. A 72-hour forecast with a probability threshold is used to confirm the heatwave occurrence. A stop mechanism exists to halt early actions if the probability of heatwave occurrence falls below 75% within 72 hours, but early actions can resume if subsequent forecasts confirm the heatwave.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: If the probability of the occurrence of a heatwave with a lead time of 72 hours is less than 75%, the stop mechanism is activated by the RCSK Head of Disaster Management upon receiving the message from Kyrgyzhydromet. This stops the implementation of early actions. If later forecasts confirm the heatwave, early actions are resumed.

trigger_statement_1.statement: Based on a comprehensive work, the trigger for the EAP was identified and it will be triggered if the seven-day forecast of Kyrgyzhydromet indicates that temperature will exceed the 85th percentile for three (3) and more consecutive days during June – August throughout the life cycle of the EAP with a lead time of four (4) days for the selected local points. The trigger will be monitored according to the official weather bulletin which is released by Kyrgyzhydromet in a range of two (2) degrees. Having the local and regional models with high resolution, the forecast for 72 hours will be used as a confirmation of heatwave occurrence. If the probability of the occurrence of a heatwave with a lead time of 72 hours is less than 75%, The Stop Mechanism will be activated by the RCSK Head of the Disaster Management Department upon receiving the corresponding message from Kyrgyzhydromet. Following the activation of the stop mechanism, the implementation of early actions will be stopped accordingly. During the heatwave warning period, the RCSK FbF team will be informed of the updated forecast twice a day (08:00 and 12:00 local time) by the responsible Kyrgyzhydromet staff. Based on this, if the later forecast (after the activation of the stop mechanism) confirms the upcoming heatwave, then the early actions should be continued accordingly.
thresholds: Temperature exceeds the 85th percentile for three or more consecutive days during June to August
Lead time of 4 days for selected local points
Forecast monitored with ±2 degrees tolerance
72-hour forecast used to confirm heatwave occurrence
Heatwave occurrence probability with 72-hour lead time less than 75% triggers stop mechanism
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Kyrgyzhydromet
trigger_statement_1.lead_time: 4 days (initial trigger), 72 hours (confirmation and stop mechanism)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Selected local points across Kyrgyzstan during June to August; intervention areas include Chui, Issyk-Kul, Talas, Batken, Jalal-Abad and Osh provinces
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Upon trigger activation, early actions include distribution of food parcels and hygiene kits to vulnerable families, distribution of colouring books and pencils to children, installation of air conditioners in care homes and orphanages, installation of information boards with protective measures, conducting information campaigns and early warning SMS system. Stop mechanism can halt these actions if heatwave probability falls below threshold, but actions resume if forecast confirms heatwave again.

trigger_mechanism.description: The trigger mechanism is based on flood forecasts issued by the Flood Forecasting Division (FFD) of Pakistan Meteorological Department (PMD). There are three types of flood bulletins (A, B, and C) with varying lead times and forecast details. Activation occurs when Bulletin C and significant flood warnings predict very high to exceptionally high flooding with river flow above 150,000 cusecs at Nowshera station of Kabul River with 3-5 days lead time. Following this, early warning dissemination and beneficiary identification start. The actual cash distribution is conditional on confirmation by Bulletin A or B within 24-48 hours lead time. A stop mechanism exists if Bulletin A or B do not confirm the high flood threshold, halting cash distribution.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: Cash distribution is stopped if flood bulletin A (Qualitative Flood Forecast) or flood bulletin B (Quantitative Flood Forecast) from FFD/PMD do not confirm very high-level flooding with flow above 150,000 cusecs at Nowshera station of Kabul River within the next 48 hours.

trigger_statement_1.statement: The activation trigger will be reached when flood bulletin C (Weekly River’s Catchments Forecast) and significant flood warning/advisories from FFD/PMD predicts very high to exceptionally high flooding with river flow above 150,000 cusecs at Nowshera station of Kabul River with a lead time ranging from 3-5 days. Following the activation trigger with 3-5 days lead time, PRCS will start the process of dissemination of early warning messages to the target population along Kabul River basin. The early warning messages will be in accordance with the government, based on the flood categorization and significant flood advisories (alert messages) and bulletins (evacuation messages). The activation trigger with a 3-5-days lead time will also trigger the identification of the most vulnerable communities for AA intervention (in consultation with respective provincial and district management authorities), followed by validation/registration of beneficiaries for the cash assistance including funds disbursement to the financial service providers (FSPs) and their retailers. However, the distribution of cash to registered beneficiaries will be implemented within 24hr - 48hr lead time when the flood bulletin A (Qualitative Flood Forecast) or flood bulletin B (Quantitative flood forecast) from FFD/PMD confirms a very high-level flooding with flow above 150,000 cusecs at Nowshera station of Kabul River within the next 48hrs. This means a stop mechanism is put in place with regards to distribution of cash in case the flood bulletin A or B from FFD/PMD do not confirm the aforementioned very high flooding thresholds in Kabul River.
thresholds: River flow above 150,000 cusecs at Nowshera station of Kabul River predicted by flood bulletin C and significant flood warnings/advisories with 3-5 days lead time
Confirmation of very high-level flooding with flow above 150,000 cusecs at Nowshera station of Kabul River by flood bulletin A or B within next 48 hours
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Flood Forecasting Division (FFD) of Pakistan Meteorological Department (PMD)
trigger_statement_1.lead_time: 3-5 days for activation trigger; 24-48 hours for cash distribution confirmation
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Kabul River basin, specifically Nowshera station
trigger_statement_1.condition_dependency: Cash distribution is conditional on confirmation by flood bulletin A or B after initial activation by flood bulletin C and significant flood warnings/advisories
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Dissemination of early warning messages to target population; identification and registration of most vulnerable communities for anticipatory action; funds disbursement to financial service providers and retailers

trigger_statement_2.statement: Currently, the Flood Forecasting Division (FFD) of Pakistan Meteorological Department (PMD) issues three kinds of flood bulletins regularly; Bulletin A provides a qualitative forecast of river level including Kabul River with a maximum of 3 days lead time, Bulletin B provides a quantitative forecast of river levels for the next 24 hours, Bulletin C is the weekly river catchment forecast providing qualitative information on the river level with maximum of 5 days lead time.
thresholds: Bulletin A: qualitative forecast with up to 3 days lead time
Bulletin B: quantitative forecast for next 24 hours
Bulletin C: weekly qualitative river catchment forecast with up to 5 days lead time
trigger_statement_2.source_authority: Flood Forecasting Division (FFD) of Pakistan Meteorological Department (PMD)
trigger_statement_2.lead_time: Bulletin A: up to 3 days; Bulletin B: 24 hours; Bulletin C: up to 5 days
trigger_statement_2.geographic_scope: Kabul River and other river basins in Pakistan

trigger_mechanism.description: The Early Action Protocol (EAP) for drought in Kenya is triggered based on the Standardised Precipitation Index (SPI) forecast for the October-November-December (OND) season issued by the Kenya Meteorological Department (KMD). The trigger activates when the SPI value is below -0.98 with at least a 33% chance of occurrence in at least 3 of the 23 Arid and Semi-Arid (ASAL) counties. Upon forecast issuance, the drought risk map is updated using the IBF dashboard incorporating the new forecast and IPC phase projections. Counties meeting the threshold are ranked by risk index, and those classified as alarm or emergency by NDMA are excluded. The EAP is then triggered in the top 3 remaining counties. The lead time for this trigger is up to 12 weeks, allowing early actions to start in July. There is no mention of a stop or deactivation mechanism in the document.

trigger_statement_1.statement: This EAP will be triggered for the 23 ASAL counties of Kenya where Standardised Precipitation Index (SPI) forecast for OND from KMD indicates SPI value of below -0.98 with at least 33% chance of occurrence, in at least 3 counties. The lead-time will be up to 12 weeks and early actions implementation will start in July. When KMD issues OND forecast which indicates that the trigger levels will be exceeded in at least 3 of the 23 ASAL counties (prioritized for this EAP) Kenya, the drought risk map will be updated by the IBF dashboard, factoring in the new forecast information and IPC phase projections (hazard component of the risk index). The counties in which the trigger threshold is met will be ranked by order of the risk index. Of those ranked, NDMA’s current information will be considered such that if any of them is classified as alarm or in emergency state of drought (too late to conduct anticipatory actions), then they are dropped and focus is given to those in alert and/or normal. The EAP would then be triggered in the remaining top 3.
thresholds: SPI value below -0.98
At least 33% chance of occurrence
Threshold exceeded in at least 3 of the 23 ASAL counties
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Kenya Meteorological Department (KMD), Integrated Drought Risk Assessment using IBF dashboard and IPC phase projections
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: 23 Arid and Semi-Arid (ASAL) counties of Kenya
trigger_statement_1.condition_dependency: Trigger depends on forecast exceeding threshold in at least 3 counties; counties classified as alarm or emergency by NDMA are excluded before final trigger activation in top 3 remaining counties
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Updating drought risk map with new forecast and IPC projections; ranking counties by risk index; excluding counties too late for anticipatory actions

trigger_mechanism.description: The Early Action Protocol (EAP) for droughts in Zimbabwe uses a two-stage trigger system based on meteorological forecasts and food security assessments to activate early actions. The first trigger is based on a forecast of an El Nino event indicating a once-in-six-year impact level, activating low investment early actions. The second trigger is based on a forecast of IPC 4 food insecurity conditions in FEWSnet Food Security Forecast Reports in March and June, activating more intensive early actions addressing food insecurity. The second trigger is normally conditional on the first trigger but can activate independently if the first trigger is not met, provided the IBF model detects drought by April and the Government of Zimbabwe declares a drought.

trigger_statement_1.statement: First Trigger: A forecast of an El Nino event, with an impact level corresponding to a once-in-six-year event, will act as the first trigger for low investment Early Actions (Early warning dissemination, drought tolerant seed distributions, and livestock dosing).
thresholds: Forecast of an El Nino event with an impact level corresponding to a once-in-six-year event
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Impact Based Forecast (IBF) Drought model combining ENSO forecasts, CHIRPS Data, and Vegetation Condition Index
trigger_statement_1.lead_time: 7 months lead time starting from September to the end of the agricultural season
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Zimbabwe
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Early warning dissemination, distribution of drought tolerant seed varieties, and livestock dosing initiated in October following the seasonal forecast issued by the Meteorological Services Department confirming the El Nino forecast.

trigger_statement_2.statement: Second Trigger: A forecast of IPC 4 conditions in the FEWSnet Food Security Forecast Reports in Both March and June will trigger the second set of early actions that address drought-induced food insecurity (livestock support, Multi-Purpose Cash Transfers, and school supplemental feeding). The second trigger would normally only be activated following the activation of the first trigger. If the first trigger is not activated the second trigger will only activate if the IBF model detects a drought by April and a drought is declared by the Government of Zimbabwe.
thresholds: Forecast of IPC 4 conditions in FEWSnet Food Security Forecast Reports in March and June
If first trigger not activated, activation requires IBF model detection of drought by April and official drought declaration by Government of Zimbabwe
trigger_statement_2.source_authority: FEWSnet Food Security Forecast Reports and Impact Based Forecast (IBF) Drought model
trigger_statement_2.lead_time: March and June forecasts; drought detection by April if first trigger not activated
trigger_statement_2.geographic_scope: Zimbabwe
trigger_statement_2.condition_dependency: Normally conditional on activation of the first trigger; if first trigger not activated, requires drought detection by IBF model by April and government drought declaration
trigger_statement_2.preliminary_actions: Livestock dosing support, Multi-Purpose Cash Transfers to 500 households, and school supplemental feeding targeting primary schools in affected wards.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP trigger mechanism is a dual-trigger system requiring two conditions to be met for activation: first, an alert of the El Niño phenomenon issued by COPECO/CENAOS with a specified probability; second, a forecast of severe precipitation deficit in the dry corridor. Both triggers must be met to activate early actions. The system includes a stop mechanism based on updated quarterly climate outlook forecasts.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: The stop mechanism is activated with the update of the quarterly forecast of the climate outlook for the following month, effectively interrupting the activation when the forecast no longer meets trigger conditions.

trigger_statement_1.statement:
Trigger 1 
When COPECO/CENAOS issues an alert warning of "El Niño" in area 3.4, for the next 3 months with a 60% probability based on the IRI forecast from the OND quarter (year -1) and except for AMJ and MJJ quarters (Predictability barrier).
thresholds: El Niño alert in area 3.4 for the next 3 months
60% probability based on IRI forecast from the OND quarter (year -1)
Excluding AMJ and MJJ quarters due to predictability barrier
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: COPECO/CENAOS using IRI forecast
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Honduran territory, specifically area 3.4 related to El Niño
trigger_statement_1.condition_dependency: Trigger 1 must be met before Trigger 2 can activate the EAP

trigger_statement_2.statement:
Trigger 2 
When COPECO/CENAOS issues a climate outlook bulletin where a serious precipitation deficiency is forecast when the accumulated rainfall for the next 3 months is between the 10th and 20th percentile in the dry corridor starting in the (March-May) MAM quarter (year 1) with a probability from greater to 60%.
thresholds: Accumulated rainfall for the next 3 months between the 10th and 20th percentile
Forecasted serious precipitation deficiency
Probability greater than 60%
Starting in the March-May (MAM) quarter (year 1)
trigger_statement_2.source_authority: COPECO/CENAOS climate outlook bulletin
trigger_statement_2.geographic_scope: Honduran dry corridor
trigger_statement_2.condition_dependency: Trigger 2 activation is conditional on Trigger 1 being met

trigger_mechanism.description: The Early Action Protocol (EAP) uses a two-tiered trigger system for drought anticipatory actions. The first trigger (pre-activation) is based on the seasonal outlook issued by the Lesotho Meteorological Services (LMS) in September indicating below normal rainfall, which initiates early warning messaging dissemination and preparedness activities. The second trigger (activation) requires three cumulative conditions: (i) the first trigger was activated in September, (ii) rainfall during October, November, December (OND) is confirmed below normal, and (iii) a Vulnerability Assessment Analysis report (by LVAC) issued in January projects that 20% of the population will be in drought-induced IPC Phase 3 and 4 in January. Upon meeting the second trigger, unconditional cash transfers are activated. The triggers are conditional, with the second trigger dependent on the first. There is a stop mechanism where the EAP Manager can recommend stopping activation based on assessment and confirmation of changes.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: The EAP Manager, upon assessing and confirming changes in conditions, will recommend concurrently to the Programme Director and Pall to order the stoppage of activation.

trigger_statement_1.statement: LRCS will activate a two-tiered trigger. The pre-activation trigger is reached when LMS issues the seasonal outlook in September with below normal rainfall and this will initiate the dissemination of early warning messaging (EWM), and preparedness and monitoring measures of the upcoming conditions. The second trigger is reached when all following three conditions are met: (i) the first trigger was activated in September, (ii) the October, November, December (OND) rainfall was indeed below normal (iii) the Vulnerability Assessment Analysis report (by LVAC) issued in January projects 20% of the population in drought-induced IPC Phase 3 and 4 in January in anticipation of the March/April main harvests for the next six months.
thresholds: Seasonal outlook issued in September indicating below normal rainfall
October, November, December (OND) rainfall confirmed below normal
Vulnerability Assessment Analysis report issued in January projects 20% of the population in drought-induced IPC Phase 3 and 4 in January
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Lesotho Meteorological Services (LMS), Lesotho Vulnerability Assessment Committee (LVAC)
trigger_statement_1.lead_time: Seasonal outlook in September (approximately 2-3 months ahead of main harvest in March/April)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Southern Lowlands and Senqu Valley regions of Lesotho
trigger_statement_1.condition_dependency: The second trigger is conditional on the first trigger being activated in September
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Upon the first trigger (pre-activation), dissemination of early warning messages to 5,140 households (20,560 people) is initiated, including community training, public gatherings, media broadcasts, and SMS alerts to target populations.

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP trigger mechanism is a single-trigger system based on temperature forecasts from Hydromet of Tajikistan and CoES alerts. The trigger activates early actions if temperatures in Gorno-Badakhshan Autonomous Oblast (GBAO) fall below the 1st percentile (below -39.0°C) and in other areas (Districts of Republican Subordination, Sughd, and Khatlon provinces) fall below the 2nd percentile (below -21.1°C) for three or more consecutive days, based on a 4-day (96 hours) weather forecast with a 4-day lead time. Activation involves communication from Hydromet to RCST and IFRC, followed by mobilization of branches and coordination with partners. There is a stop mechanism if the probability of occurrence of the cold wave falls below 85% with a 48-hour lead time.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: The stop mechanism is activated if the probability of occurrence of a cold wave is less than 85% with a lead time of 48 hours. The FbF coordinator proposes activation of the stop mechanism based on consultations with Hydromet, and the RCST Head of Disaster Management department endorses it.

trigger_statement_1.statement: This EAP will be triggered based on forecast to be provided by the Hydromet of Tajikistan and CoES alert, if temperatures in GBAO exceed the 1 percentile/PCTL [at temperature of below -39.0°C] and in all other areas of DRS, Sughd and Khalton exceed 2 percentile/PCTL [at temperature of below -21.1°C] for 3 or more consecutive days based on the 4-days [96 hours] weather forecast with the 4 days of lead-time that the RCST will have to prepare for an extreme cold wave before it strikes.
thresholds: Temperature in GBAO below -39.0°C (1st percentile) for 3 or more consecutive days
Temperature in DRS, Sughd, and Khatlon below -21.1°C (2nd percentile) for 3 or more consecutive days
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Hydromet of Tajikistan and Committee on Emergency Situations (CoES)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Gorno-Badakhshan Autonomous Oblast (GBAO), Districts of Republican Subordination (DRS), Sughd, and Khatlon provinces in Tajikistan
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Upon trigger activation, Hydromet sends forecast email to RCST Head of Disaster Management and FbF Project Coordinator, who inform IFRC and relevant branches. Coordination with CoES and local authorities is initiated. Readiness activities include selection of targeted people, volunteer training, and prepositioning of NFIs such as electric oil heaters, window and floor insulation materials, and essential food commodities.

trigger_mechanism.description: The trigger mechanism is a single-trigger system based on weather forecast alerts issued by Kazhydromet. The simplified EAP activates when an Orange level weather alert or higher is issued, indicating extreme cold wave conditions with specific temperature thresholds combined with precipitation and increased wind speed persisting for at least two days in any district. The National Society begins preparation upon trigger activation and continues monitoring to implement early action activities. There is no explicit stop or deactivation mechanism described.

trigger_statement_1.statement: Orange level of weather or higher threat according to the Kazhydromet6, which means: If the 7-day temperature forecast of Kazhydromet shows the minimum temperature will go below -40˚C (-35 ˚C in Karaganada region) with precipitation and increased speed of wind and such conditions persist for at least two days in any district. (https://www.kazhydromet.kz/ru/weather/in_city_7_days) the simplified EAP will be activated. When the trigger is met, the National Society starts preparation for the activation and continues monitoring the situation to activate early action activities. If the 3-day map alert of Kazhydromet forecast temperatures consistent with the table below in any targeted district the early action activities will be initiated. (https://www.kazhydromet.kz/ru/meteoalert). Orange level in the selected regions identifies when the temperature is the following7: Region Temperature Northern Kazakhstan -40 ˚C Akmola region -40 ˚C Kostanay region -40 ˚C Pavlodar region -40 ˚C Eastern Kazakhstan (incl. Abay region) -40 ˚C Karaganda region -35 ˚C Monthly and decade forecast from Kazhydromet will be used for the general weather conditions predictions.
thresholds: 7-day temperature forecast minimum below -40°C (-35°C in Karaganda region) with precipitation and increased wind speed persisting for at least two days in any district
3-day map alert of forecast temperatures consistent with Orange level thresholds in targeted districts
Region-specific temperature thresholds for Orange level: Northern Kazakhstan -40°C, Akmola -40°C, Kostanay -40°C, Pavlodar -40°C, Eastern Kazakhstan (including Abay) -40°C, Karaganda -35°C
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Kazhydromet
trigger_statement_1.lead_time: 7 days (7-day forecast) and 3 days (3-day map alert)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Northern Kazakhstan, Akmola, Kostanay, Pavlodar, Eastern Kazakhstan (including Abay), Karaganda regions
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Upon trigger activation, the National Society starts preparation for activation and continues monitoring the situation to activate early action activities. Preparatory actions include pre-contracting food service providers, mapping homeless gathering places, awareness raising about food distribution and social adaptation centers, agreements with police and social services for transportation of homeless people, preparing databases of vulnerable groups, and mapping bus stations, truck parking, gas stations, and cafes at city exits and highways.

trigger_mechanism.description: The Early Action Protocol (EAP) for heatwaves in Tajikistan is activated based on official weather forecasts issued by Tajik Hydromet. The trigger is a single trigger based on forecasted temperature thresholds exceeded for consecutive days during the summer months. The forecast uses multiple global and local models, with BAGROV model providing the best skill. Activation occurs when forecasted daily temperatures exceed defined thresholds for 4 consecutive days in specific districts. The lead time for activation is approximately 5 days. There is a stop mechanism that allows halting early action if the heatwave changes track before community notification or distribution begins.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: If the heatwave changes track dramatically before materials are distributed or communities notified, the distribution of relief items will be stopped and materials returned to storage. If rerouting is not feasible but originally targeted communities are still expected to suffer impacts, distributions will continue as planned.

trigger_statement_1.statement: The trigger for this EAP will be activated when Hydromet issues a forecast of the day temperature exceeding 39.5°C in the North and 43.5°C in the South for 4 consecutive days in the period of July-August. The expected lead-time for activation is 5 days.
thresholds: Day temperature exceeding 39.5°C in the North for 4 consecutive days during July-August
Day temperature exceeding 43.5°C in the South for 4 consecutive days during July-August
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Tajik Hydromet using BAGROV, COSMO, ECMWF, and WRF models
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Northern and Southern regions of Tajikistan, specifically districts listed with temperature thresholds (e.g., Kabodiyon, Nosiri Khusrav, Shahritus in Khatlon; Rudaki in DRS; Asht, Khujand, Mastcho, Zafarobod, B. Gafurov in Sughd; Dushanbe in Capital; etc.)
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Upon receiving weather alerts, RCST notifies IFRC to trigger DREF fund allocation, calls urgent meetings with CoES to activate early actions, and coordinates with branches to follow agreed instructions. Volunteers and branches prepare warehouses, communication, and logistics for rapid response within 3-5 days lead time.

trigger_mechanism.description: The simplified Early Action Protocol (sEAP) activates when both observed conditions and forecast criteria are met in a respective city/municipality of the southern Terai region of Nepal. Observed conditions require daily maximum temperature and relative humidity thresholds to be exceeded. Forecast criteria require either a red alert heatwave bulletin from the Department of Hydrology and Meteorology (DHM) or a Numerical Weather Prediction (NWP) forecast exceeding the 99th percentile temperature threshold for three consecutive days. Both observed and forecast conditions must be met simultaneously for activation. The protocol is designed as a dual-trigger system with conditional dependency between observed and forecast criteria. No stop or deactivation mechanism is described.

trigger_statement_1.statement: The simplified Early Action Protocol (sEAP) will be activated in a respective city/municipality of the southern Terai region of Nepal when both of the observed conditions and forecast criteria are met:
thresholds: Observed Conditions: Daily maximum temperature (Tmax) exceeding 41°C in Nepalgunj, 40.5°C in Dhangadi, 37.5°C in Biratnagar, 40.5°C in Siddharthanagar
Observed Conditions: Relative humidity (Rh) of 45 percent or higher in the respective city where Tmax condition is met
Forecast Criteria: DHM issues a red alert heatwave bulletin ('take action') for the next 3 days in the target city or its associated district
Forecast Criteria: Numerical Weather Prediction (NWP) from DHM forecasts daily maximum temperature above the 99th percentile threshold in the target city/municipality for the next 3 consecutive days
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Department of Hydrology and Meteorology (DHM)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Southern Terai region of Nepal, specifically Nepalgunj, Dhangadi, Siddharthanagar, and Biratnagar cities/municipalities
trigger_statement_1.condition_dependency: Forecast criteria activation is conditional on observed conditions being met first (both Tmax and Rh thresholds)
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Pre-activation assessments include community-based verification to validate beneficiaries, identification of vulnerable groups through government databases and local authorities, and early awareness campaigns accessible to all. Readiness activities include consultation meetings, volunteer mobilization, training, and agreements for communication and cash transfer. Early actions include distribution of cash, safe drinking water, electrolytes, establishment of shading and cooling spaces, health care mobilization, and ambulance provision for severe cases.

trigger_mechanism.description: The Early Action Protocol (EAP) for drought in Niger uses a multi-stage trigger system with three distinct triggers based on meteorological forecasts, forage biomass assessments, and food security analysis. Each trigger activates specific early actions targeting vulnerable communities. A deactivation mechanism exists to stop early actions if updated forecasts or satellite data show significant improvement before the early action window closes.
trigger_mechanism.stop_mechanism_description: A deactivation mechanism applies if updated forecasts or satellite monitoring show a significant improvement in rainfall or vegetation cover before the window for early action closes, ensuring efficient allocation of resources.

trigger_statement_1.statement: Trigger 1: The CRN will launch a first phase of early action in April/May based on a forecast of 40% or more below-normal rainfall provided by the European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF). When the ECMWF forecasts indicate, in April, a probability of 40% or more of having below-normal rainfall totals over the period July to September in a region or department, we will coordinate with the national meteorological service to carry out a downscaling. This will make it possible to identify the communes and villages likely to be affected, which will then become the intervention areas for trigger 1.
thresholds: 40% or more probability of below-normal rainfall totals over July to September
Forecast issued in April
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF) and national meteorological service
trigger_statement_1.lead_time: Approximately 3 to 5 months ahead (forecast issued in April for July-September period)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: Regions or departments in Niger, downscaled to communes and villages
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Awareness messages (radio, megaphone), vaccination with vitamins, minerals and deworming, distribution of drought-adapted and improved short-cycle seeds, post-distribution evaluation

trigger_statement_2.statement: Trigger 2: When the results of the Ministry of Livestock's forage biomass assessment, carried out in November, indicate a fodder deficit of up to 40% or more in a locality (commune or village), the NS will activate the second trigger and intervene in these localities with the specific early actions.
thresholds: Fodder deficit of 40% or more
Assessment conducted in November
trigger_statement_2.source_authority: Ministry of Livestock
trigger_statement_2.geographic_scope: Localities (communes or villages) in Niger
trigger_statement_2.preliminary_actions: Awareness messages (radio, megaphone), conditional cash transfer for livestock feed, vaccination and deworming

trigger_statement_3.statement: Trigger 3: Finally, if the November Cadre Harmonisé results indicate that a region will be in IPC Phase 3 or higher due to drought, the NS will anticipate a difficult lean season. To do this, NRCS will use the data from the evaluation of the agricultural season of the Ministry of Agriculture to determine the communes and villages in deficit in the concerned region. These localities will then constitute the intervention areas for the third trigger early actions.
thresholds: Region in IPC Phase 3 or higher due to drought
Cadre Harmonisé results from November
trigger_statement_3.source_authority: Cadre Harmonisé analysis and Ministry of Agriculture
trigger_statement_3.geographic_scope: Regions in Niger, downscaled to communes and villages
trigger_statement_3.preliminary_actions: Awareness messages (radio, megaphone), conditional cash transfer allowing poorest households to access cereals free of charge

trigger_mechanism.description: The EAP trigger mechanism for tropical cyclones in Fiji is a multi-stage system based on forecasts from the Regional Specialized Meteorological Centre (RSMC) in Nadi. It includes a readiness trigger activated by the unofficial 120-hour (5-day) forecast indicating winds of at least 64 knots in zones with at least 5,000 people, followed by an action trigger activated by the official 72-hour (3-day) forecast meeting the same wind and population conditions. Additionally, there is a post-event observational trigger based on average rainfall over two consecutive days. The triggers are sequential and conditional, with readiness preceding action. Notifications are automated and disseminated to relevant stakeholders. There is no explicit stop or deactivation mechanism described.

trigger_statement_1.statement: This simplified EAP will be triggered by a tropical cyclone that is forecasted by the Regional Specialized Meteorological Centre (RSMC) in Nadi to cause winds of at least 64 knots11 in zones where at least 5,000 people lives12 . The trigger comprises 2 stages, each of which is triggered based on the lead time of the points in the forecast: 1. Readiness13 trigger: If the wind field indicated by the 120-hour forecast meets the trigger conditions, the readiness14 trigger is met. 2. Action trigger: If the wind field indicated by the forecast up to a lead time of 72 hours meets the trigger conditions, the activation trigger is met.
thresholds: Tropical cyclone forecasted to cause winds of at least 64 knots (Category 3 on Australian scale)
Population in affected zone at least 5,000 people
Readiness trigger: wind field indicated by 120-hour (5-day) forecast meets conditions
Action trigger: wind field indicated by 72-hour (3-day) forecast meets conditions
trigger_statement_1.source_authority: Regional Specialized Meteorological Centre (RSMC) Nadi, Fiji Meteorological Services, OCHA Centre for Humanitarian Data, Fiji NDMO
trigger_statement_1.lead_time: Readiness trigger at 120 hours (5 days), Action trigger at 72 hours (3 days)
trigger_statement_1.geographic_scope: National coverage of Fiji, specifically zones where at least 5,000 people live
trigger_statement_1.condition_dependency: Action trigger is conditional on the readiness trigger being met first based on lead time forecasts
trigger_statement_1.preliminary_actions: Upon readiness trigger: activation of internal processes for fund release, prepositioning of funds and items, notification of logistics providers, movement of staff and volunteers, checking prepositioned items, stakeholder coordination, confirmation of target communities and households, dissemination of early warning messages, door-to-door messaging, health messaging, distribution of shelter support kits (SSKs), livelihood items, and collection of community feedback.

trigger_statement_2.statement: The National AA Framework also includes a third trigger, which is a post event observational trigger: If the average rainfall over the whole country during two consecutive days meets the threshold (190 mm), the observational trigger is activated.
thresholds: Average rainfall over the whole country during two consecutive days reaches 190 mm
trigger_statement_2.source_authority: National Anticipatory Action Framework, Fiji Red Cross, Fiji Meteorological Services, NDMO
trigger_statement_2.geographic_scope: Whole country of Fiji
trigger_statement_2.preliminary_actions: If only the observational trigger threshold is met, Fiji Red Cross will seek rapid response funding from the DREF Response Pillar to conduct pre-agreed actions.
